description: Until our SF visit, we've never seen a Peruvian restaurant let alone a food truck. While wandering around SF, Google maps led us to Sanguchon and we thoroughly enjoyed our meals. I had the Pan con Chicharron and my wife had the Barbacoa. The food was freshly made and delicious. The staff was super friendly and more than happy to explain the menu to us. We highly encourage you to try Sanguchon.  If there's a long line, don't be impatient; you'll be happy you waited for this fantastic meal.
author: John And Tracy C.

description:
Being Peruvian iv been meaning to try this cart when working in the financial district. I usually arrive as they're closing or forget cash but today I made it and im glad I did. I ordered the 
Pan con chicharron sandwich combo meal.

The sandwich was really good. Quality bun that didnt fall apart topped with alot of tender juicy lime and rocoto sauce sliced pork with onion and fried yam. I had to get an inca cola for my drink and the side of sweet potato fries were good but id have prefered if the more traditional yucca fries were still on the menu.

Good food but being a food cart make sure you check the location on the website, find nearby seating, and bring cash.
author: Sean G.

description:
I've never had a bad meal from Sanguchon.  I know their prices have gone-up a bit, but you get a solid meal that packs a lot of flavor.  The Lomo Saltado is tender cuts of NY Sirloin, with tomato, onion, cilantro and soy sauce.  Plus they top if off with french fries and cream de rococo sauce.  It's my fave sandwich, it's well seasoned and always cooked just right.  Plus, they use an artisan roll on their sandwiches, which is also a nice touch.  

For you pork fans, feel free to try their Barbacoa, which is their BBQ pulled pork.  If you like pork loin, go with the Pan con Chircharron, which has amazing flavor.  

I know they have bowls too, but I always opt for their sammies.  They can get a bit messy, but your taste buds won't be disappointed.  For their sides, try their sweet potato fries.

Service is friendly and fast on this truck.
author: Lon H.

description:
I decided to try this food truck for lunch a couple of days ago as it was parked close to my place of work. At the peak lunch hour there was a line about 3 deep. As this was my first time I was taking a little too long to decide on what to order, which did not go down too well with the impatient server manning the register so she prodded me on. I decided to get the special of the day which was Peruvian style chicken curry with rice and decided to add a fried egg to it bringing my total to $14 with tax.

My order was ready as soon as it was placed and I was on my way. I got a small container which had about a scoop of rice on the right and about a ladle of chicken curry on the left. There was a small amount of Peruvian style lime picked onions and a blob that filled in for a fried egg. Taste wise the chicken curry had an overwhelming taste of raw peanuts. There were a couple of pieces of what seemed to be boiled chicken that were folded into the peanut based sauce. In addition, it was extremely salty. The rice was of decent quality and was cooked right. The fried egg was a cold hard blob that was probably fried earlier in the day and then frozen before being served. The best part of the dish was the pickled onions. Overall this was a poor excuse of a dish.

Price-wise, it was not too high considering FiDi and food truck (which itself adds a couple of bucks to the price) but it was not worth the food that I got. Goes without saying, I did not like it at all and have no intention of returning.
author: Ahmad J.

description: Pan con chicharron, extra onions please. Sad that the truck is no more but excited for the brick and mortar!
author: Daniel W.

description:
It's a Tuesday night and driving to Petco we saw the normal crowd and said why not? So I saw the Peruvian truck and I saw my favorite dish the pan con chicharron which is a pork sand which and I grew up eating it as breakfast in Peru. 

The way I remember it! - crunchy well fried pork served salsa criolla which is an onion base salsa type with lime, and cilantro! Goes well with any dish actually. 

Tonight I stopped by the sanguchon truck and of course I got the pan con chicharron and I'm sad to say that I was very disappointed. First of all, if I would have known it was spicy I wouldn't have gotten it! Also, the cream or spread if you might was kinda sweet - not very original?! And they used white onion with cilantro as their criolla. It also had ONE slice of sweet potato which was BURNT! 

I would like to give this place another shot but after tonight I might just skip the second chance. Wish el sanguchon nothing but good luck!
author: Fernanda D.

description: Had the chicharron / pork loin sandwich - it's awesome with the grilled onions and sauce - each bite is delicious - they keep the truck kitchen real clean too
author: Raul M.

description: I had the opportunity to try out Sanguchon Peruvian Food Truck last Friday and was quite happy with their barbacoa sandwich though it was quite pricey at ~$11. I wasn't sure what to expect especially since one of the listed ingredients within the sandwich is potato chips. I was surprised to find that the potato chips really paired with the other items in the sandwich very well! The meat is very juicy and tender and I loved the barbecue sauce that it is mixed in. Overall, I found the sandwich to be very delicious and fulfilling though I do think it is a bit expensive for what it is.
author: Joshua M.

description:
You've heard of TLDR.  Well, this is my TLDW (Too Long, Didn't WRITE) review.

Lomo Saltado is always delicious and tender and always finish off your meal with some Alfajores.
author: Jamie J.

description:
Lomo Saltado Bowl.  The meat was salty, chewy and dripping with oil.  They ran out of rice during my visit and subbed in sweet potato fries instead.  The rice would have cut the oily over-seasoned Peruvian stir fry to make it more bearable while the fries offered nothing besides more or less of the same, something mired in grease.

For FiDi standards, it was overpriced at $12 but this seems normal for food truck--a platform for unproven chefs to test their favorite dishes, with reactions ranging for delight to disgust.
author: Amy J.

description:
EDITED

The pork sandwich was quite good. When I ordered the chicken burrito, the rice was soggy, the chicken tasted flavorless and overcooked, and the whole thing was dry and bland. It left a gross feeling in my stomach and the cooking oils used were subpar. Do not recommend.
author: Andre W.

description:
Peruvian food exists in San Francisco in small doses, I just wish there was more of it.  This truck serves the obligatory Lomo Saltado over rice (traditional) or on a sandwich bun (not-so-traditional).  Pretty solid quality for a food truck, though I'll take a hole-in-the-wall Peruvian restaurant any day.

Lomo Saltado Bowl: Good flavors and tender meat, but a tad dry.  I suppose that's somewhat understandable because their primary usage is to put this on a sandwich, but it'd be nice if there was an excess of that soy-based stir fry sauce to soak into the rice.  Somewhat related, I would have preferred if the fries were stir fried with everything else so they soak up some more flavoring and soften a bit.  But the creamy sauce on everything was very nice and helped moisten things.  I kinda respected their choice to use the New York Strip cut over the Tenderloin to keep prices reasonable.  I mean, this is a food truck, not a trip to La Mar.

Platano Frito: These are ripened plantains, maduros.  Sticky and crunchy.  Kinda like a dessert, except for the bits of salty cheese chunks.  Works as a pairing though.
author: Adam B.

description:
Yum! This was my first foray into Peruvian food, and I have to say it was no disappointment. I ordered the Lomo Saltado sandwich for $10, plus a fried egg on top for an extra dollar. I don't know how authentic it was to Peruvian cuisine, but nonetheless it was delicious! The protein was a stir-fried NY strip sirloin and then there were also fries, a delicious white cream sauce, onions, and cilantro, all on a French roll. Wow, what a blend of flavors and textures! The meat was wonderfully cooked and juicy and the fries added a bit of crunch and substance to the sandwich. Onions were well-marinated and between the onions and soy sauce, neither overdid their flavor contributions. 

However, the fried egg on top was somewhat of a disappointment. I wouldn't get it again, nor would I recommend this addition. The egg was entirely cooked, so the yolk was completely solid. It would have been fantastic if the yolk was still fluid, leaving it to drip and add a little additional wetness to the rest of the sandwich.

Anyway, for $11 this was a pretty good sandwich. If it were close by I'd go here again, but not before trying other nearby options. Next time, no fried egg though!
author: John B.

description:
Tried Sanguchon at Stonestown Off the Grid, I just had to try the Lomo Saltado.... I was reading everyone's reviews... and my sandwich did not have fries. Instead it came with a side of sweet potato fries (which I hate, just in general I do not like them)
But overall the sandwich was very good and filling BUT without the side sauce they give you I feel the sandwich would just be BLEEEH.

The flank steak was very soft and easy to eat, but missing flavor. The onions were perfectly sauteed and the bread i would recommend maybe applying melted butter then toasting it to have a better crunch to it. The (i think) chipotle type sauce they give, honestly makes the sandwich overall delish.
author: Cynthia C.

description:
Whoa...I haven't reviewed a food truck in nearly 18 months?  Well, other than Halal Cart and NY's Halal Guys, but those aren't really food trucks (more like food carts...).  I guess that's what happens now that I've found a set of trucks that I like (and fallen hopelessly behind on reviews).  Then again, it's not like I've written reviews for favorites like The Chairman.  BTW, did I mention that I'm hopelessly behind?

The first time I ever saw Sanguchón, I was quite excited to eventually check them out.  OTG used to be somewhat lacking in variety (even I can only take so many types of Asian tacos), so seeing a Peruvian food truck was pretty refreshing.  Especially after learning it's a sister eatery to Piqueo, which is a favorite of one of my friends.

Although I had planned on trying the Lomo Saltado sandwich, I caved to my love of pork and audibled to the PAN CON CHICHARRON - Sliced Pork Loin with Fried Yams, Lime Juce marinated Onions, and Cream de Rocoto ($9).  The taste as a whole wasn't bad (I liked the tartness/acidity of the onions), and the yams were okay, but the meat needed some help.  Fat obviously isn't good for you, but it certainly would have added some flavor and juiciness to the lean (and dry) pork loin.

Despite being underwhelmed by my sandwich, Sanguchón deserves some points for their sizable portions.  While food trucks in general have a reputation of being overpriced for what you get, the sandwiches are a decent value (taste aside).  In fact, I ended up only eating about half of my sandwich and bringing home the rest (which actually tasted better when I reheated it the next day).

Given their generally favorable reviews and their connection to Piqueo, I wonder if I just came on a bad day.  It's also possible I just ordered the wrong thing, as my friend seemed to enjoy the Lomo Saltado I shoudl have ordered.  Perhaps that's the way to go, though I'd be lying if I said making a point of finding out was high on my list.
author: Mike L.

description:
Was really disappointed with my Lomo Saltado Bowl w/ fried egg. I really wanted to like it but there was something wrong with all major components of it: 
- temperature of food was lukewarm
- steak was very dry and tough
- fries had zero flavor
- rice was undercooked, crunchy rice is the most disgusting IMO!
- fried egg?!? lol...was not fried, it was probably microwaved and yolk was solid not runny. For sure not worth the extra dollar.

Maybe this was an off day but I don't think I will be visiting this truck again anytime soon.
author: Sharon L.

description: Not very strong. The chicken bowl was a few dollars more than it was worth. It was small. The quality of the chicken wasn't great, mainly brown meat. Normally saltado is juicy, while this one was dry and had no sauce or juice. So that made the rice very plain as well because I couldn't mix it with anything. Was hoping for more.
author: David G.

description:
My family and I were introduced to Sanguchon at Off the Grid in Oakland. OMG, everything was delicious! I couldn't have been more pleased (especially in lieu of the fact that I have to cover all of the bases with my son's food allergies, which can be difficult.) With the former being said, we had ZERO issues regarding cross contamination, or hidden ingredients. My husband, son, and I ALL enjoyed the great food Sanguchon offers.

We tried the Pan con Chicharron and Barbacoa sandwiches, with sides of sweet potato fries. The pork + fried yams + onions + sauce combination was divine! The pulled pork BBQ sandwich was also very flavorful and good. At times, I tend to be disappointed with food truck meals; yet, this was NOT the case with Sanguchon! Top notch food and flavors.
author: Amber L.

description:
You must either get their Pork Chicharron Sandwich or their Lomo Saltado Sandwich!  Either one is well flavored and a super meaty Sammie!  

During lunch hours on Tuesdays and Thursdays at this location, you can just smell the alluring aroma of the meat that is being cooked up at this food truck!  You can't help, but go to it!

The cashier was nice enough to add meat for an extra dollar since I had my credit card and not cash with me that day!  The minimum charge on a credit card is $10.

I was nom-ing away at my loaded and tasty Sammie for lunch!
author: Tiffany D.

description: Great sandwiches, my favorite is the chicharrón sandwich with sweet potato also good daily specials and yummy Lucuma smoothie and desserts great too.
author: Sonia N.

description:
I am a huge fan of this spot. Here's why: 
1. Sanguchon has never let me down. Every time the food is consistently amazing. 
2. The thought of lomo saltado in a sandwich struck me as genius! They are the first ones I've ever heard of putting this awesome Peruvian dish in a sando. Also, their bread is on point and made exclusively for them and the quality of the meat is really up there. Practically melts in ur mouth and joins hands with all the other flavors going on (which btw, includes French fries, soy sauce, the rocoto sauce, and veggies). This sandwich Can hold its own with any fancy sit down restaurant sandwich. It's really that good! I also really appreciate that they have a bowl, because although the sandwich is absolutely 100% the way to go, the healthily inclined can still get in on the action. I did once but I missed the bread. 
3. That rocoto sauce is money. And goes especially well with the sweet potato fries you should be getting a side with your lomo saltado sando. 
4. Passion fruit juice and Inca Kola and chicha morada (definitely try the chicha at least once. It's made from purple corn and it's awesome) aren't necessarily things you can find anywhere. They are all perfect for washing down that lomo saltado sandwich and sweet potato fries. 

Although they don't park necessarily close to my office I have no problem taking the walk out to wherever they may be. The trucks schedule is posted online and has always been accurate. 

In sum, get you a lomo saltado combo, with sweet potato fries and a chicha morada or maracuya ( passion fruit).
author: Thielson D.

description: I was not impressed with this food truck. Food was generic, not interesting and not too flavorful. Too much of  sides and not much of proteins. There are much better food trucks out there. I am giving four stars only because I don't like harming small businesses.
author: Andy D.

description:
I was a bit surprised to see that the Lomo Saltado was a sandwich. Having spent some time in Peru, I was expecting a stir fry. I almost sent DH back to tell them it's the wrong thing!

It's fancier, more upscale, than traditional Peruvian food. The crem de rocoto sauce was elaborate, with many spices and herbs. The bun was fine, but I would have preferred the traditional presentation. There was a lot of mayo. I liked the extra flavor the french fries provided, but there's not a whole lot in the sandwich. They made it fresh, so it was nice and hot, but there was a bit of a wait. The steak, NY strip, seemed very tasty and tender. The whole sandwich cost $9.

Food overall was slightly better than 3 stars. DH would have probably given them 4. DH says, "Pretty tasty. I wished they had a non-sandwich form. I liked that the meat was well seasoned. Not sure I'd pay that much for it again." They get an extra star for having Inka Cola ($2), which is an artificially flavored banana soda usually found only in Peru. Cool!
author: Kari C.

description:
I follow the norm. I question food trucks without any customers at Off the Grid events. I try popular, well-know vendors with long lines and over-hyped food items (ie: Senor Sisig, Curry Up Now). But what particularly drew me into Sanguchón Peruvian Food Truck was their (new) adorable pig logo! The original logo was a silhouette of a realistic-looking pig. But the new one is a cute, chubby, cartoon-like pig with a chef hat.

But carrying on...

Sanguchón's food is delicious and very satisfying for a food truck. They offer sandwiches, wraps, and a few sides. I'm not a big fan of wraps, so I've only tried their sandwiches. The Pan con Chicharron has pork loin, fried yams, marinated onions, and aji rocoto aioli. There was a generous portion of tender pork loin, the yam added a mild sweetness, the onions were strong, and the aioli was creamy and good, a little peppery without being spicy. I wished there were more sauce though, because I found the sandwich to be overall a bit dry. The bread has a slightly crunchy exterior and soft inside. The Barbacoa has pulled BBQ pork, with coleslaw and potato chips. A generous portion of meat satisfied my quickly, but I was disappointed with the inconsistency. Some pieces of pork were tender, and some were very tough and chewy. The coleslaw and chips and cabbage added some nice crunch though.

They offer sandwich combo meals (sandwich + sweet potato fries) for $10. The sweet potato fries weren't anything too special. I wouldn't order them on their own, nor would I order them in a combo meal again. I'll save myself the $2. Yucca fries seemed to be a popular side item, but I didn't enjoy them. Some pieces were undercooked and almost crunchy in the middle. They were a little bland without the dipping sauce. Overall, these fries reminded me of why I hate thick-cut fried potatoes: there's just too much starch.

If you have the rare, secondary dessert-only stomach, try the alfajores. Sandwiched between two crumbly shortbread cookies is a luscious, creamy, and smooth dulce de leche filling. $5 for two of these cookies is steep, but it's worth the price tag because they're so good! I wished they were packaged differently though; upon opening, it gets messy because the powdered sugar spills everywhere.

Sanguchón specializes in sandwiches and a few snacks, so overall the menu isn't very extensive. Service is pretty quick and friendly. Supposedly the first Peruvian food truck in SF, they don't seem too very popular, yet.
author: Priscilla W.

description: Barely any meat was included in the order. I basically paid $13 for rice and fries. Definitely never getting lunch from here again.
author: Ed L.

description: Lomo Saltado Sandwich $11 a pop  Stir fried Ny strip sirloin with tomato, onion, cilantro and soy sauce. Topped with French fries and cream de rocoto. Top it off with a friend egg for an extra $1 (worth it).  Solid option for the area, service is friendly and the food comes out pretty quick.
author: Rod M.

description: I've eaten at this truck a lot because it parks right outside my office. The Lomo Saltado and Chicharron sandwiches are both great. I also like to order the sweet potato fries.
author: Cynthia M.

description: Today was my third time eating at this place. The first 2 times I had the lomo Saltado bowl and it was amazing. Today it was terrible. It was quick but the meat and rice were lukewarm and NO flavor whatsoever. Matter fact it needed salt. I'm not sure what happened but I'm disappointed.
author: Patricia C.

description:
4.5 Stars

Lomo Saltado is a true winner: portions are fantastic, meat is flavorful/tender and the sauce is to die for

Overall Thoughts

If they keep this up a 5 star is in the near future!
author: Eddie W.

description:
I only had the lomo saltado bowl ($10) with egg (extra $1) for lunch.  The bowl was decent, it didn't blow me away but the beef was tender.  It needs more seasoning and if I were to order this dish again, I will probably skip the egg.

The line is hella long even on a gloomy day, so I'll have to come back to check out other items.  They take cards.
author: Amihan M.

description:
I came to Sanguchon for their Lomo Saltado sandwich ($8) and added an egg and a side of yucca fries. The premise of this sandwich is amazing, they put fries IN the sandwich! 

Unfortunately, I felt like all the ingredients were mediocre at best. The beef in the sandwich was a bit dry, the bun was meh. Overall, not a terrible sandwich but if looking for a good sandwich I'd go somewhere else. Yucca fries were pretty legit.
author: Jess C.

description:
I had a not-so-great experience with the food at La Constanera, Sanguchon's sister restaurant, so I avoided this food truck for a while. But seeing the long lines at Off the Grid week after week, I finally got the nerve to try it.

Twice, I've gotten their combo special. $10 for a sandwich and sweet potato fries.

Pan con Chicharron Sandwich: pork loin, fried yams, marinated onions & aioli. The pork looked deceivingly dry. And it was when you eat it by itself. But in the sandwich, it was so delicious! The "dryness" of the pork added texture while the aioli gave it a spicy kick.  

Lomo Saltado Sandwich: New York steak with tomato, onion, cilantro soy sauce & fries. The steak was in juicy chunks. It tasted just like lomo saltado, so no complaints there.

Sweet Potato Fries: pretty standard. I was given a pretty generous portion the first time having the combo. The second time, smaller portion.
author: Marti L.

description:
For Street Food, boy was this tasty. Sanguchon in Spanish basically means "really big sandwich," and while they were bigger than a lot of hamburgers, it wasn't big enough to get me stuffed.  Size was just right. Got Lomo Saltado Sandwich, Stir fried New York steak accented with tomato, onion, the pepper gave it a little spice, some soy sauce & drum roll please... fries! The fries soak up the oil of the meat so the sandwich is still crunchy. Hate oily sandwiches so this worked out great!

Best part is that the bread doesn't get soggy, the french bread was firm enough to offer a solid foundation for the sandwich yet light enough to not be chewy.

Yucca fries were crispy on the outside but still soft and creamy in the middle.  Very rich!  Sauce though was very mild, it was supposed to be spicy cheese sauce but lacked tha flavor, I wish it could have been more potent to bring out the flavor of the fries. Overall, Another food truck checked off! Happy tummy ...happy customer!
author: Maria M.

description:
The first two times I went and got the chicharron sandwich it was one of the most flavorful and tasty (those can be different) sandwiches I had ever eaten.  The onions were crazy tasty, the pork juicy and mouthwatering, the sauce complemented everything and the bread was fresh.  Awesome and five stars!

Today I had the same sandwich and every ingredient was two notches below and I felt really let down because I know what this sandwich could have been.  The bread was not as fresh and the meat was dry.  Not sure if a new cook was working or they switched suppliers, but I hope the owners read this review and focus on quality of the product.  I would love my favorite sandwich in the area to remain my favorite sandwich in the area.
author: Curtis C.

description:
The Lomo Saltado wrap is my favorite! It's main ingredient is diced NY Strip steak which is always perfectly cooked, tender, and lean (I can't do fatty steaks, nerve endings, sinews, etc.). Other ingredients include grilled tomatoes, onions, and french fries. Pure bliss!

I go for the combo deal which includes Sweet Potato fries and a drink for a few bucks over the $10 mark (I get the Inka Cola! Imagine a light bubble yum-flavored soft drink).

I haven't tried the other sandwiches because I'm a creature of habit. The Lomo Saltado was the first sandwich I tried here, and I haven't been able to pry myself away and get something else.

TIP:
The Lomo Saltado wrap is easier to handle than the sandwich, which is also awesome but it can get messy. The wrap is something you can take back to your desk and enjoy with little to no mess.
author: Jr G.

description:
I've been wanting to try one of their sandwiches for awhile.  Luckily they've been setting up camp on Tuesdays & Thursdays near my office on the corner of Spear & Mission.  I told bf about this and he's had their sandwiches several time.  I'm a sucker for Lomo Saltado but he told me he liked the roast pork sandwich more.  So, I took his advice & went with the Pan Con Chicharron ($8).

It was so good!  They didn't skimp on the pork at all.  The sandwich was filled with lots of huge chunks of moist pork with a little crispy skin on some pieces.  I liked the round bun like bread they used too.  The fried yam was the perfect compliment too adding some creaminess to the sandwich.  The marinated onions were a little sour for my liking, but nonetheless it was a great sandwich!  

I think they may possibly take card?  I went yesterday to pick up a late lunch for my bf, and asked if they did, however she said cash only today.  Thanks Sanguchon for curing the FiDi lunch time blues!  I can't wait to go back for another, next time I think I may try the Lomo Saltado.
author: Cat C.

description:
Sadly, I believe I ordered the wrong thing. After deliberating for way too much time between their popular lomo saltado and their chicken wrap, I got the latter and was not super pleased with the meal. I am by all means a carb lover, but even this was too much for me, as the wrap must have been 90% rice, potatoes, and the outer shell a.k.a. carbs on carbs on carbs. The non-carb parts tasted simply like peanut butter with chicken. I also love peanut butter, so the flavor only became a problem because it was really the only one present. A lot more salsa/veggies would have spruced up the monotone dining experience.

Definitely get one of their sandwiches on their custom-made artisan rolls if you go. I expect that I will upgrade my rating once I taste one of their signature entrees.
author: Amy G.

description:
Delicious! Had the Barbacoa (Barbecued Pulled Pork, Coleslaw Peruano, Potato Chips & Salsa fusion $8) for the first time today and really enjoyed it. One thing I was surprised by was the size, it was huge!
The bun was filled to the point it was spilling out into the box with heaps of Pulled Pork and tasty Red Cabbage Slaw and what I found the most interesting - a layer of potato chips. Kind of took me back to my childhood days of having potato chip Sandwiches. The Pork was quite sweet and worked very well with the Slaw but was incredibly messy, I suggest bringing extra tissues with you when you visit this truck because you will probably need them.

I also really wanted to try the Alfajores (Cookies filled with Dulce de Leche) but they had ran out really early into service. Noooo! Sad Emmalou. Maybe next time.

The lady taking orders was very nice and they worked through the vast amount of orders quickly and with ease. Can't wait to try more.

* Update August 2012 *
I've returned to Sanguchon a few more times now and just as impressed as I was the first time around! I've also now tried the Alfajores (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/40V85s2E2nJdcoNLVl7eKQ?select=yu4CIaIF7-fCJst_46yxKg#isjW3WJzsQpNIBkkFYI2lg) Flaky, buttery biscuits filled with smooth Dulce de Leche and dusted with a huge amount of powdered sugar. Delicious! The only thing I wasn't so keen on was the amount of sugar on top, I had to scrape most of it off as it was just too much for me but best food truck cookie so far!
author: Emmalouise B.

description:
Sanguchón is one of the food trucks that reliably serves the food that I know will hit the spot. As a result, on days when I am not feeling particularly up to checking out the other Off The Grid offerings, they are my go-to truck.

I love the pan con chicharron and the barbacoa. Both are served in rolls that hold really well to their moist meats. The chicharron is always plentiful, flavorful pork and the barbacoa is just always reliably smoky goodness. Their sweet potato fries are good but after I ordered it once, I never did again. It is just way too much food for me as their sandwiches are one of the biggest sandwiches I have seen served, which makes them a really good deal (something that one cannot always say about food trucks).

If you want hearty, delicious sandwiches, give Sanguchón a try.
author: Clarice O.

description:
Ordered the lomo saltado sandwich at Off the Grid in Menlo Park; seriously must have been an off day or something? The beef was extremely tough and flavorless; tomatoes were mushy and sandy. Overall the quality of the ingredients seemed subpar and the flavors left much to be desired. 

I've had my share of delicious lomo saltado and this missed the mark. Waaaay off. Definitely overpriced for what I got in terms of quality and amount.
author: Vicky L.

description:
I'm always willing to try some Peruvian food in the Bay Area and SANGUCHON did not disappoint me. My Dad and I are both from Peru and were reminded of those amazing Peruvian flavors. 

Highly recommend the Pan con chicharrones which is pork with sweet potato and criolla sauce with a very nice aji sauce. A combo with soda and sweet potato fries was a well spent $12. 

My Dad had the lomo saltado bowl and it was awesome. The meat was tender and very flavorful. 

I will return to this food truck to try the rest of their menu which includes 3 sandwiches, a couple of bowls and even alfajores for dessert. 

Check their website for location. We found them in San Carlos by the Hiller Museum.
author: Martin R.

description:
What's to say about this place that hasn't already been said? I don't know. All I can tell you is that the Chicharron sandwich, while being Peruano, tastes like a carnitas burrito, sans tortilla. Or, a torta, sans avocado. Their buns are, where do they have these specially made? They're very Vietnamese baguette textured. They're light, but substantial enough to hold all of that satisfying porky deliciousness. They have enough crevices to let the beautiful Peruvian aji rocoto, resembling a bell pepper, turned into an aioli, seep into them. Let's not forget the lime marinated onions and cilantro. It just wouldn't be the same without the onions. However, those fried yams basically could have not been there. They didn't provide anything extra, and they were flacid. Yo, Sanguchon, 86 the yams unless they're crispy.

Then, they have yucca fries and yucca balls. Look, white people, I love you. But, it's not pronounced yuh-ka, it's you-ka. Don't let Alton Brown and those other babblin' blanquitos on the food channels make you feel self-conscious about saying it the proper way. I hesitated on the yucca ball special, due to my adversity with olives, so by living vicariously through my dining companion that bought them, there wasn't much of an insurance risk. Low and behold, they surprised me, for two reasons.

I was surprised that they weren't as crunchy as I expected them to be, so that satisfying crunch thing wasn't happening. But, they had that wonderful earthy, nutty flavor that yucca is supposed to have when cooked properly. I was also surprised that the olives are basically non-existent. Instead, you have a well-balanced, hyper-flavorful filling with Spanish chorizo and raisins. If they were only crunchier, these things have the possibility of being extremely addictive. And no one wants to see a gorda pacing on Park Street trying to hook herself out for yucca balls.

No one.
author: Illyanna M.

description:
I love yucca fries and plantains, so decided to check out Sanguchon at Moveable Feast in Willow Glen last week. There wasn't a line at the time, so it took less than 10 minutes to order and receive our food:

-Yucca Fries & Huancaina Sauce ($4, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sanguchon-peruvian-food-truck-san-mateo?select=I_Hp_-j1E7Cese9m5BvFIg#I_Hp_-j1E7Cese9m5BvFIg): Not very good- the yucca pieces were too thick for my preference, and the huancaina sauce wasn't very flavorful.
-Platano Frito (Fried Plantain w/Honey & Cinnamon, $4, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sanguchon-peruvian-food-truck-san-mateo?select=I_Hp_-j1E7Cese9m5BvFIg#L_red_k_Xu53_HKcf0h2SA): I normally love plantains but didn't like this version at all for some reason. The honey and cinnamon flavors didn't really come through and the plantains just had a sticky texture. 

Overall, I was disappointed in the sides I purchased, but do want to come back and try their sandwiches. Maybe they were just having an off night where the yucca fries were cut too thick or something. The people working there were really nice, so I feel terrible giving them a 2 star rating, but I just didn't enjoy the items I tried that night. However, I will hopefully be back for those sandwiches soon!
author: Amy D.

description:
Sanguchon is a regular vendor at Off the Grid Emeryville. Before heading out to OFG, I already lowered my expectations because I was going towards the end of the event. It was about 1:20 and OTG ends at 2pm. Despite scaling down my hopes, I was still shocked at the poor quality of food. I ordered the Pan con Chicharron sandwich combo with sweet potato fries ($10). I literally received my food right after signing my receipt. I get it, not all food trucks prepare their food on the spot when the customer orders. But can't you at least try to give the impression that you do? My sandwich was cold and my sweet potato fries...well they were the worst sweet potato fries I've ever eaten in my life. They weren't even worthy of being called fries because they were basically flimsy and soggy strips of sweet potatoes. 

I was suspicious when the young lady handed me the container because it wasn't warm. I flipped open the lid and disappointment immediately drowned any excitement I had for my meal. The fries looked like a limp pile of orange sticks. They were cold and not crispy at all. A soggy fry is a sad fry. And this made me sad. 

Fine, I'll suck it up because the sandwich looked promising. The Pan con Chicharron consists of chunks of pork loin, fried yams, and marinated onions sandwiched between two pieces of French bread. A zesty aioli sauce welds all of the ingredients together. It was actually pretty tasty and Sanguchon does not skimp on the meat. However, my sandwich was cold. Everything was cold: the buns, pork, yams, sauce. EVERYTHING. The pork loin wasn't roasted around the edges or moist in the middle. The French bread was hard and stale, zero crunch when you bite into it. The sandwich would have been excellent if it was served hot and fresh.

Sanguchon probably wanted to avoid running their fryers or stoves after the big lunch rush in order to conserve energy and money. But seriously? That is no excuse to sell crappy food. It wasn't 10 minutes before closing, there was still 40 minutes left! Maybe Sanguchon could have at least microwaved my food (as gross as that sounds). I'm extremely disappointed that this business would serve cold food that was pre-made and sitting around for God knows how long.
author: Judy H.

description:
FAIL. Refused to make any food without mayo at a catered event. 

1) the menu didn't say it came with mayo. 

2) you're assembling sandwiches on demand. 

3) pro tip: offer mayo on the side.
author: Steve K.

description:
The Peruvian food truck is one of five Off-the-Grid food trucks parked in the UN Civic Center Plaza every Thursdays. This is also one of my bookmark businesses to try too. And I'm glad I found that particular food truck.

Like every Off-the-Grid events, there is always a long line, especially for lunch. 

The cool logo of the truck is like looking myself in the mirror. "Oink!" Logo: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/I2aW4QywdLgZJzdweu967w?select=cDvUp_iEa2J2Rj9sPXgaMw

My main target from the Peruvian food truck is the Pan Conchicharron sandwich. For $8.00, the sandwich has a lean pork loin, a Peruvian-blend Salsa and tangy aioli sauce in a bun. The lean pork meat mixed with the key ingredients is very unique and one of a kind. 

I also had an Iced Peruvian drink called the Chicha Morada with my sandwich. I don't know what the drink comprised, but it had a taste of cinnamon, cloves and chopped apples. But the drink is sole and refreshing. 

I ate my food on the bench provided by the organizer of the events. But still weirdos (I'm not one of them) and the homeless were still asking me for a bite and money. A sad scene it was that is unavoidable. 

I definitely enjoyed the Peruvian food truck and support the Off the Grid events, but they need to keep those nuts away from the paying customers who are enjoying their foods.    

My meal: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/I2aW4QywdLgZJzdweu967w?select=TV8qOZgWWkCJvgVIRzNTVw
author: Matt G.

description:
It's alright.  Partially my fault for waiting so long to write a review, but that shows that while the food was good, it's not super memorable.

I'd like to know what Sanguchon means--every time I look at it, I think it's Korean because it makes me think of gochujang.  Anyways, onto the review:

Pan con Chicharron, $8 (Pork loin slivered, fried yams, marinated onions & aji rocoto aioli): very filling and carby because the bread is thick, which makes it a little difficult to eat.  The pork/onions/aioli isn't bad, but overall the flavors just don't really come together to make an amazing sandwich.

Sweet Potato Fries , $4 (Sweet potato fries with sweet rocoto sauce): pretty standard sweet potato fries, probably frozen seeing how homogenously perfect they were.

I got the combo for ~$10 because I wanted to try more food, but it's probably not recommended because it's so filling.  Enough carbs and sodium for a week :( :)

Sorry, no photos!  With Off the Grid, it's just too difficult because you need to hold your food, and the bright sunlight makes it nearly impossible to see your phone screen.  Plus, sandwiches taste best warm and toasty, which is not worth sacrificing for a photo, much though I admit to being an Asian taking pictures of food.
author: Edna C.

description:
Peruvian food is often expensive so if you're on a budget it's a roll of the dice.
The great thing about this food truck is that it's the same owner as La Costanera
That's the Michelin rated restaurant that's three times the price.

You can typically find them at the Off the Grid near Haight on Thursday night.
Peruvian food that's fast and done right.

Get the lomo saltado sandwich, it has seasoned steak and french fries inside.
The fried plantain has honey and cinnamon, the dude would abide.

The chicha morada is a sweet corn drink, they also have yuca fries.
This is one of my favorite food trucks I will not tell a lie.
author: Kristi G.

description:
We tried Sanguchon Peruvian Food Truck on Fri 2/24/12 when MVBLFeast was in Curtner, SJ.

It was early when we went so didn't have to wait in line.

We got:

Pan Con Chicharron Sandwich $8 - It comes with 2 giant thick bread, lots of thick chunks of roasted pork some very dry pieces, some fried yams I asked on the side w/ raw onions, some white sauce.  I thought the bread didn't go well with the sandwich had to eat the bread torn into bite size pieces & meat dipped in sauce.  Just ok for me.

Lomo Saltado $8 - J. got it, I tasted a slice of the beef, just ok, fries, thick bread.  She thought Pan Con Chicharron was better.

Chicha Morada $2 - sweet purple corn drink, I liked it ok.

Alfajores $4 - 2 cookies come in a package for $4 - they are big cookies that are shortbread w/ caramel inside & tons of powder sugar, very crumbly, I liked them.  I would get this again if I ever saw the truck again.

They have 3 sister restaurants: Mochica, Piqueos, La Costanera.

Website menu:
http://www.sanguchonsf.com/menu/
author: Ann L.

description:
Hit or miss. 
Last week it was divine, this week it was wretched. Therefore I have deduced it's hit or miss, the pan con chicharron was bland and there was so much fat on it...absolutely ridiculous. I had to spit out half of the meat.The yuca fries were disgusting. The sweet potato fries were the best part, but they really need to give you more sauce! 

Overall I would probably go here if there was no other option, I wouldn't have what I've previously ordered unless it was the sweet potato fries, with extra sauce.
author: Sara N.

description:
I'm a a big fan of these guys .. they're friendly, serve really tasty and high quality food, and wait times are reasonable compared to food truck standards. 
I usually get one of the bowls and love the taste and portion. Just wish they were near my office more days!
author: Shirin E.

description: Pretty good, but pricey and quality has not been as consistent lately. The pork gets too overcooked and crispy. Eggs get often overcooked as well. I usually go for lomo saltado or chicharron bowl. Rice is better than average.
author: Aleksey ..

description:
Great food, friendly service. I work around Rincon and looking forward to Tuesday lunches because of the truck. 

Barbacoa wrap is fantastic, try it with an egg.
author: alex w.

description:
When I first heard about Sanguchon and their Peruvian Sandwiches, I was really looking forward trying them.  I've visited them on a few occasions.  Twice at Off The Grid Upper Haight and once at the Brisbane Marina.

First time was pretty good.  It was their first time at Off The Grid Upper Haight and they had quite a line.  I had their Pan con Chicharron (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=F_5_UNX-wrAFCXuAkBZRDw&select=SROiyLJ6upN6tfLsa4zYOg).  It was a moderately sized sandwich but they did load it up with Roast Pork which was very tasty.  And the Fried Yams were good too worked well together with the pork.

Second time at OTG Upper Haight took forever.  They didn't seemed backed up but they were putting out a lot of orders.  I ordered the Pollo a la Brasa.  It wasn't as good as the Pan con Chicharron.

Over at Brisbane, there wasn't a long line so I got my order pretty quick.  I had their Lomo Saltado (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=F_5_UNX-wrAFCXuAkBZRDw&select=x1Ww20Nz887gFYX406NcQQ).  I think this is my favorite sandwich from them.  How can you not like Steak and Fries in a sandwich?  It's just a perfect harmony of flavor and texture!!

Sanguchon makes really interesting and tasty sandwiches.  If they ever happen to be in your area, defintely give them a try!
author: Rodney H.

description:
Pollo Saltado Bowl or Lomo Saltado Bowl. I alternate. They are both delicious, but don't forget to ask for the fried egg! Make sure you use the little cup of sauce they give you. It's so good! Sometimes I ask for a second one. My coworkers are now hooked on Sanguchon, even the one who always said she hated Peruvian food. She actually went there today, on her own, and got the Pollo Saltado Bowl.  I haven't had anything other than the bowls, but my coworkers have and they love everything! I go here at least once a week, sometimes two. If they were near my house I would probably have it for dinner all the time. 

Love this place!
author: Maria Z.

description:
This food truck came to my work today and the fact that it was Peruvian food got me excited, but overall, it was just okay.  I got to the truck towards the end of the shift that they pretty much had the sandwiches already made and ready-to-go.  I tried the Barbacoa sandwich which consisted of BBQ pulled pork, coleslaw, and potato chips on a ciabatta bread.  Not sure about the potato chips in the sandwich.  I ended up taking it out.  

The sandwich was still warm, but not hot.  It came with a side of sweet potato fries, but because it was sitting there, it was pretty soggy especially with the sauce on it.  The sandwich was really messy that it required a lot of napkins and although it had generous portions of pork, the sauce just tasted like American BBQ sauce so I was a little disappointed.  Hope to try some of their other menu items next time.
author: Erica S.

description:
Very good food truck serving Peruvian food. I had the Pan con chicharron and the Alfajores cookies with dulce de Leche which is made in house. The sandwich was very good and the cookies were good too (a little expensive at $5 for 2) despite the powdered sugar on it. 

(----rant begin----)
Powdered sugar sucks. Why do people use powdered sugar on beignets, cookies and such? It really does not add to that much to the flavor and is super messy and hard to get off clothes. 
(----rant end----)
author: Sunil R.

description:
I always get the Lomo Saltado combo from Off the Grid. The sweet potato fries with the delicious aioli dressing or the "platanos Frito's are great as well with the rich and sweet maracuya drink.
One of my favorite trucks
author: Jose Jesus V.

description:
I had just experienced a thwarted effort in finding something new to eat last Friday, and then on my mopey walk back to the office, I happened upon this Truck and took a chance. And yikes! was I happy! THEIR LOMO SALTADO IS THE BEST THING I'VE HAD TO EAT IN 2016! I couldn't recommend it more.

It was so good, I brought a buddy back today and got it again! Have Mercy! :)
author: Jesse D.

description: I saw my sister standing in line in front of the sanguchon food truck at alameda OTG.  I asked her to order me the lomo saltado and she said "no, I'll order you the pan con chicharron, trust me". So I was like ok. OMG, probably one of the best sandwiches I've had in awhile. So delicious I am salivating right now just thinking about it! The sandwich came with crispy pork loin with yams, marinated onions, and aioli sauce on a soft bun. Such a flavorful combination in my mouth. I literally demolished the entire sandwich, it was that good!
author: Jocelyn T.

description:
Pan con Chicharrón = to die for.  Juicy, slightly crisp pork inside a bun.  A (thick) slice of yam on top of the  chunky pork, and some other delicious toppings, including the aji aioli!   I had to stop halfway through, as I was getting way too full! 

I was crazy enough to get a side order of the sweet potato fries, which were delicious, but like I said, way too full! 

All of this was in a combo for $10.00!!  It was fantastic!

Service = friendly.  They execute it in a timely fashion.

They accept cash and cards.  

I went around 11 a.m. to avoid the rush and long lines.  But it gets hairy from 12 to 1, per the usual.

Prices = moderate for food truck style!  

I'm making myself drool describing this........
author: Fannie S.

description:
I had the combo Pan con Chicharron sandwich with sweet potato fries on the side with passion fruit juice.

For me, it's a HUGE sandwich, maybe just right for others.  The sweet potato fries were hot and crispy, and didn't get soggy as I was eating my sandwich.

The sandwich bun was perfect,  Soft enough, but not mushy soft and it contained the pork which was slightly crispy.
author: Louise G.

description:
Last week at OTG Upper Haight, http://s3-media4.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/pI4bak-Vba4u2HI3DZ8BNQ/l.jpg was the debut of the first Peruvian sandwiches food truck from chef/owner Carlos Altamirano (Mochica, Piqueo's, and La Costanera restaurants). http://s3-media2.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/4d9-ONCV4KtE0_Ee1LWzww/l.jpg

The menu has 4 sandwiches ($7-8), 2 wraps ($7-8), mostly fried side dishes (yucca, sweet potato, plantains and others) for $4-8, and traditional Peruvian drinks like chicha morada, maracuya and Inca Kola for $2. http://s3-media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/ix0Mpzz6Wtv1FD9YVG-J7w/l.jpg Other items like tamales, tacu tacu, etc. will be featured in the future.

The most popular items are Pan con Chicharron, and a sandwich version of Lomo Saltado, both at $8. Not exactly cheap, but it's the first to specialize in this style of sandwiches from Peru. Super tender meat, salsa criolla (marinated onions) and nice heat from a rocoto chile aioli. Delicious stuff! http://s3-media3.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/GFYaQD0kKvIXZ4y7zl3QHQ/l.jpg I haven't tried the wraps yet.

Service was excellent, very well organized system. Itemized receipts too (one of the few trucks that take credit cards). It was packed with customers that day. Place your order at the right side window. http://s3-media2.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/Owp6f0OqbAhx08oOjDlpkA/l.jpg And wait at the pickup window (left side). A staff person was helping expedite orders, called order numbers, and distributed the food. http://s3-media2.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/P_YvA6zy9sxoc5Y6yRJaLQ/l.jpg

If u check my previous reviews, both El Perol (AM only) and Rincon Peruano (weekends only) have Pan con Chicharron for less, but during limited hours. It's usually a breakfast item.

For now the truck will be on a public park corner in Potrero Hill for lunch weekdays, plus OTG events around the city.

** Update: They now have 2 trucks. So check Twitter for location updates (ignore the website). http://twitter.com/Sanguchon_SF They also have a Facebook account, but most of those posts are in Spanish. http://www.facebook.com/SanguchonSF
author: Luis C.

description:
Food trucks!! Gotta love em'! Sanguchon is no exception.

Based on the yelp reviews, the Lomo Saltado seemed to be the way to go. Stir fried New York steak with tomato, onion, cilantro soy sauce and fries, all sandwiched in between two soft pieces of sourdough bread. Enough said. There's even an option to add a fried egg for $1!

Everything about this little sandwich worked so well. The steak itself is a little dry (expected w/the stir fry), but with the sauce it was plenty flavorful and tasty. The fries in the sandwich are a nice addition too, and with the egg it was just perfect. I would definitely recommend getting the Lomo if you come here!

Pro tip: Get the sandwich + sweet potato fries combo for $10 if you don't have any cash money on hand. That'll bring you to the $10 minimum for credit cards and leave you more than satisfied!

Our group all ended up grabbing a Lomo, and after scarfing them down back at the office agreed that it was pretty much amazing. Go snag yourself this taste of Peru in sandwich form, you won't regret it! Enjoy!
author: Jason T.

description:
I ordered the Lomo Saltado! It was sooo good! The meat was seasoned just right! It had onions, fries and the bread was to die for! It was nice and toasty! 

The fried yuca was fresh but needed a little salt but I drenched it in hot sauce so that made them yummy!!!! 

Can't wait to try the rest of the menu!!! *Burp*
author: Carla F.

description:
One of the best food trucks out there.  Always on point & delicious, and always serviced with a smile.

Other food trucks should take note!
author: Jerome Z.

description:
I get out of my way to eat on this food truck whenever I can.

I've tried everything on the menu. There are good things and better things, but if you're going there for the first time, try the Barbacoa or the "Camarones Crocantes" (either bun on wrap). They're ridiculous.
author: Rodrigo L.

description:
Wow - a GREAT "roach coche" and right next to my work too.  I had the Chicken with feta cheese sandwich and sweet potato fries. Although the fries were not as sweet as others I've tasted you could tell they were made fresh and from real sweet potatoes. The sandwich itself was probably one of the messiest I've ever had so I wouldn't recommend it for a luncheon with friends, but more of a solo meal hiding at your desk.  It had influences of Indian curries with red onions and a flaky bun. I hope this truck comes back so I can try other things on the menu.

The staff inside were friendly and even giggled when I tried my hardest to pronounce their menu in as authentic of an accent as I could.  I'll keep trying.
author: Kevin J.

description:
Holy Machu Picchu, Batman!!

Had may heart set on the Lomo Saltado (Steak) but at the last minute changed it to Chicharron Pork.  The sandwich, on a fresh baked Challah-type roll had a ton of meat on it, and almost every piece of meat was moist on one end and crispy on the other.  It also had a thin sliced grilled yam, red onions and a lime and recoto (red pepper) aioli to make it slightly sweet.  Better than any torta I've had lately.  Their yucca fries were different but good, seasoned and crispy on the outside, and soft on the inside with a little cheese and parsley. They serve it with this cheese dip that has a slight garlic taste to it, and it was ok, I just took the rest home and doused it with Sriracha - maybe not as authentic but so what.  Will be back for the plantains.  Soon.

Good thing I checked their website to see where their truck was first (California/Montgomery seems to be a usual spot), and good thing I beat the lunch crowds as the line grew fast.  Now I see why.
author: Sal M.

description:
Pan con chicharron is a decent carnitas style sandwich.
pros - crispy pork meat, fresh artisan bread
cons- the pork was dry, and lacked flavor. somewhat disappointing from all the 4 and 5 star yelp reviews.
food trucks are not the easiest food environments to deliver a quality product, but i definitely have had better meals. and at $10 including a small side of yucca fries, it's not that good a deal.
JYW says meh
author: Jeff W.

description:
Went to this food truck at the SOMA StrEAT food park and it was absolutely delicious! 

Had the lomo saltado, yucca fries and chicha morada.  The meal was delicious and very filling! I wish the meat would've been sliced up into smaller pieces rather than being huge chunks of meat, but either way, I'll still come back for more! The yucca fries were nice and crispy and something I crave randomly throughout the day.. Also, the chicha morada was fresh and yummy but not as cinnamon-y as other chicha drinks I've had. 

Overall, one of the best Peruvian spots in SF.  If you are near this food truck, definitely stop by and try!
author: Anna G.

description: I absolutely love this food truck! The lomo saltado sandwich is delicious, I always get the combo with the sweet potato fries and their fruit punch. $12, a little pricey but it's so good i don't mind paying that and the portions are generous.
author: Irma R.

description:
True fact:

I ate a lomo saltado sandwich in my wedding dress when it was 75 degrees and sunny in March AND did not get any of the sandwich on me. 

Miracles do happen. 

It was amazing, awesome, and better than I imagined. Downside was their credit card was not working, I wish they posted a BIG SIGN saying cash only, but they didn't! Why not? Luckily we had some cash on us.
author: Dea A.

description:
I came here with my friend because they were set up at the end of Electric Run at Candlestick and had the Pan con Chicharron.

It's a pretty daunting sandwich at first sight. There's no sensible way to hold it without having chunks of pork fall out the bottom. It definitely made a good first impression before tasting it. Unfortunately, the pork was super over-fried. The outside was crispy, but the rest of the meat was very dry, sinewy, and bland. I could feel all those little muscle fibers nudging in between my teeth, and I knew I was in for a vigorous flossing session later that night. The pork wasn't seasoned very well and didn't really have any strong flavor. 

I think they relied only on the aioli and onions to provide flavor to the sandwich. The aioli had a good acidity and complimented the marinated onions well. However, those flavors didn't penetrate into the pork, and the overall flavor with everything mixed together ended up bland. On the plus side, it did provide enough energy to dance the rest of the night away.
author: Nei N.

description:
I think this was the first time I've ever had Peruvian food, so I didn't really know what to expect. I ordered the Pan Con Chicharron Sandwich ($8), but was a little disappointed. The roasted pork was really dry, and the french roll that it came on didn't go that well with the sandwich as a whole because the bread was hard to chew and not toasted well. The only thing I really liked about this sandwich was the blend of the onion and their white sauce because it gave it a really tangy taste that made the sandwich better. I also didn't think that the sweet potato did much to the sandwich overall. 

Overall, I'm not a huge fan of Peruvian food, but I might come and try something else on this menu.
author: Jeanette S.

description: DELICIOUS!! Being Peruvian, it's hard to find a spot close by for some good Peruvian food. Lucky for me, Sanguchon comes to Spear & Mission a couple of times a week. So when I get my cravings, I walk on over with my watering mouth and my tummy thanks me!!! Try it and enjoy!
author: Cynthia F.

description:
So happy to see new cuisine options for food trucks.  I JUST had Peruvian for the first time the day before and loved it.  So I was stoked to see this truck at Edgewood Eats.  The lines were crazy long, but it was worth it.

We had the Lomo Saltado (steak sandwich) and it was super flavorful.  I LOVED the bread they served it on because it was hearty enough to take on the steak without being overwhelmed, but at the same time it was soft and tasty.  I will definitely order this one again.

We also tried the Pan con Chicharron.  I am a huge fan of chicharron.  I also loved how this sandwich came with yucca which is a great compliment to chicharron.  However, my problem with this sandwich is that the huge cuts of chicharron didn't really lend itself to eating it sandwich style.  I wish they would've chopped it up a bit, maybe even did it pulled pork style.  It will also help spread out the pork more so you don't end up with all this left over bread afterwards.

I'm looking forward to following this truck and trying out their other options.
author: Judi M.

description: I'm a fan of good tasting cheap eats so when we saw this truck parked at Eat Real 2014 at Jack London Square, we were game.  We decided on the Lomo Saltado steak and fries sandwich (a generous slider-size). The tender steak was stir-fried in a delicious blend of spices and topped with white potato fries. I didn't try to analyze the stir-fry sauce, so all I can say is that it was flavorful, well-balanced and worth trying to recreate at home. Crispy sweet potato fries came on the side. The order was priced just right at $5.
author: Liv K.

description:
I got the veggie curry wrap and yucca fries.
Interesting set of veggies, including the largest corn kernels I've seen. A little bland, but still good.
Not much else for vegetarian options, but these are worth getting once to try.
I imagine Peruvian cuisine to be meat-centric, so the other dishes are probably the stars.
author: Shyam B.

description: The best food truck or lunch menu in the financial district. My favorite is the Lomo Saltado very flavorful with all the sauce sopping up the white rice and with an over-easy fried egg on top.
author: N A.

description:
Sanguchón showed up at Moveable Feast Garden City (Saratoga ave. in San Jose) and I was excited to give them a try. I ordered the Pan con Chicharron, a pork tenderloin sandwich with fried yams, onions, and a spicy mayo on a homemade roll. 

Overall, I was quite pleased with my sandwich. The pork was plentiful and was appropriately seasoned & spiced; you can tell it was slow cooked! The mayo had just enough kick, and the onions gave the sandwich a little sweet complement. I had a hard time tasting the yams bite per bite but liked their contribution to the sandwich's texture. The style of roll reminded me of a dutch crunch, which, according to my preferences, I'm not a fan of. However, I think Sanguchón's effort to present something homemade and authentic is admirable. It might require a couple tweaks (i.e. caramelizing the onions or adding bell pepper), but the pan con chicharron is a good sandwich and one I'd order again. 

My sandwich was $8, which is appropriate given the preparation of the meat, the homemade roll, portion, etc. It was an innovative combination -- or at least one Americans don't think of (I like my yams with turkey and gravy on sourdough!). Sanguchón has some other delicious items on their menu, from varieties of fries, to homemade drinks, to pulled pork sandwiches. With many trucks offering their own take on a similar type of cuisine (i.e. there are many Korean trucks, taco trucks, sandwich trucks, etc.), I think Sanguchón offers something unique and more exotic to our California taste buds. Muy bien!

Hopefully they come back to SJ again; I'd like to dig into something else they're serving up!
author: Nick P.

description:
The Sanguchon Peruvian Sangucheria was at SoMa StrEATfood Park today. The nice lady at the window said Lomo Saltado is the most popular menu item but her favorite is the Pan content Chicharron...I chose her fav.

Let me tell you, meat-lovers' galore! Juicy, fatty and huge portions; it may need more onion for acid or yam for contrast but then the focus would be taken away from the that beautiful, unctious pork *shrugs*... And that bread...OH THE BREAD(!!!) = so divine. It's made exclusively just for them.

I also ordered a can of Inca Kola (similar to that lime green-colored Harritos).

I ended the tasting with alfajores for dessert. They are Peruvian powdered shortbread cookies with dulce design Leche filling. I wanted to try these at Mochi-call in LA but didn't get the chance. Sanguchon's version is more soft, delicate and powdery than I expected but reminded me of Filipino sweets so I did not mind it. 

Overall, one of my new favorite food trucks! 4.5 out of 5. Why so high? Because I want to come back and try everything on their menu esp. all their side dishes. I'll revisit this review then to see if the 5star score should remain or be lowered. 

Until next time!

-Homer =)
author: Homer D.

description: Instead of Lomo Saltado, they had chicken saltado.  I was a little skeptical because I love lomo saltado as it is a classic - but this chicken saltado was just as tasty and good!
author: Maile N.

description:
I have been to this food truck about 4 times and have been impressed with their Lomo Saltado sandwich. The sandwich is definitely a cousin to the Mexican torta. The difference in the Lomo Saltado is their fries and the secret sauce. I feel as both of these items in a sandwich would make anything taste fabulous and sanguchon has it down to a science. 

This food truck usually is part of the moveable feast food truck fest that is South San Francisco on Gateway Blvd on Fridays. It also shows up throughout the week, but if you really want to know their schedule you can check them out on twitter under the name @gft_ssf or on Facebook.  

The sandwich consists of torta like bread,  ( I don't know the breads name so my bad!),tender slices of steak meat that are cut adequately where they are not super thick where you would gag (see my review of Curry Up Now) and are seasoned well, lettuce, tomatoes, fries in the sandwich ( the most epic part) and the best friggin sauce this side of the Mississippi. 

The service is quick but not to the point as to whether you wonder about the integrity of the food but I would suggest the lady who is taking the orders have a bit more personality. She seems disinterested and not very into the customers. 

Otherwise this place rocks. I'll keep eating their food despite that one hiccup. :)
author: Ramla J.

description:
SOGGY CHICHARRON PORK TACO
(3 stars)

They were at the SJ Festival and I would assume that Latin food would make the best tasting taco. I'll have to retract that assumption

- FOOD, average
- PRICES, affordable ($2 a taco)
- SERVICE, quick
- AMBIANCE, truck

Peruvian food is one of my favorite kind of foods. I skipped any regular peruvian items on the menu since this was a "Taco Festival" I needed to stay focus and only eat tacos. I was hoping for a WOW out of my mouth but only got a WHAT out of my mouth... WHAT the heck?!

CHICHARRON PORK TACO ($2) - When you think chicharron you think crunchy/crispy and salty. Instead, i got a spicy, saucy, and soggy taco. Was I disappointed? No, it was okay to eat... might as well called it "spicy pork soft pork taco" because there wasn't anything chicharron about it. It also had some heat, heat I wasn't expecting and didnt really enjoy it because my mouth started to burn and I gulped my taco to avoid any more heat sensation. 

INCA COLA - i hate cola, i dont drink cola... but the only cola i will drink is INCA COLA because it tastes exactly like bubble gum.

Will I be back? Probably only to quench my thirst or to try the regular menu stuff.

Until the next review.....
author: Jane A.

description:
I'm disappointed in my experience with Sanguchon.  

I like that there is a Peruvian Food Truck, but the food just isn't top quality.

-Pan Con Chicharron: For a food truck with normal food truck prices, the sandwich was actually pretty sizable.  There was a lot of food stuffed between those buns.  I also thought the seasoning for the pork was pretty good, and the combination of sauce, yams and pork worked fairly well.  However, the pork was very dry.  I like my meats moist.

-Yucca Fries:  It had an interesting dipping sauce, but the flavor of the yucca was very mild.  Pretty bland to me.  Never had yucca before.  Perhaps that is how it is supposed to be, in which case, good for them! It just didn't work for me.

Besides food, they are really slow in taking your order and preparing your order.  This is not the most efficient truck.

Of note: this is one of the food trucks that is at Stanford every week.
author: Jason S.

description: No complaints here.  A couple of weeks after I first tried it, and it has to be in my top 3 or 5 food trucks out here.  I got the barbacoa sandwich and it was delicious.  Definitely will visit again in the near future.
author: Josh B.

description:
Better than most trucks. I've been here a few times and the quality is always predictable and the service friendly. 

I think this one will be with us for a while. The Lomo Saltado is excellant.
author: Justin S.

description:
Came across them at the UN Plaza Off The Grid today (Tues.).

Tried quetanos. Warm wontons filled with cheese & ham, with an avocado salsa.
Wow! Really tasty, just the right amount of cheese, soft, creamy deliciousness, paired with a nicely salted ham and fried just long enough. 

Went back for the lomo saltado later. I could have eaten 4 or 7 more, maybe 11.

Makes me miss Peru all the more. 

I will return!
author: William M.

description:
Probably my most favorite food truck that comes as part of the Moveable Feast "quad pack" on Fridays at lunch time in South City. Had the Lomo Saltado Sandwich Combo which was $12.00, which comes with the sandwich, side of sweet potato fries (and no, yucca frieds cannot be substituted) and a drink.  Also had an order of yucca fries.  While the sweet potato fries were fairly common and what you'd expect at any joint serving them...the yucca fries were pretty bomb diggity good.  You can't really mess up on fried yucca...but this place made them in a way that just hit the spot.  Perhaps I was just super hungry, but they were perfectly fried, crispy on the outside, and soft in the inside! Yum!  The lomo saltado sandwich was pretty tasty as well... the meat was tender, but I think what made the sandwich mouth watering was the sauce they used.  I believe it's some sort of cilantro soy sauce... well whatever it was, it was slightly picante ("spicy' in Spanish) that gave the sandwich the right amount of kick.  

The line for Sanguchon at the Moveable Feast doesn't get that long, even on a busy Friday at lunchtime.  The workers are pretty fast and efficient, so it doesn't take long to order or to get your food.  Thumbs up for speed and efficiency!

For those who haven't tried this food truck..definitely give it a whirl! You'll be in for a treat.  I can't wait for the truck to come back to Moveable Feast in SSF. Hopefully they'll be here this week... I am craving some yucca fries and the lomo saltado sauce!
author: Matthew L.

description:
Sanguchon is my Moby Dick. It's ostensibly based in Potrero Hill, but I have never ever been able to find it there. So when I came across it sitting there all pretty and serenely at Off the Grid: Fort Mason, I was like, "Where's my harpoon? I'm gonna get me my whale!"

Without even reading the Yelp reviews to see what the most popular pick was, I went for the Lomo Saltado. It just seemed designed for me. Let me paint you a picture: stir-fried strips of NY steak accompanied by tomatoes, onions, creamy cilantro-soy sauce and fries...ALL IN THE SANDWICH! What the what? And the bread! I'm not even a bread person, but that bun was some upscale, epicurean shit that was even better than the bread sandwiching those $20 "gourmet" burgers you find at fancy restaurants. Mmmm!

I backpacked through Peru and had some amazing food at restaurants and by home cooks. Sanguchon is not trying to be "authentic" in any way, but rather use traditional Peruvian ingredients (like yucca, cilantro, onions and beef) in sandwiches. The end result is a party in your mouth and everyone's invited.
author: Josephine L.

description: I ordered the Pollo Saltado bowl.  I was told it would be white meat chicken, but I was given dark meat.  The flavor was very underwhelming.  The tomatoes and onions did not taste fresh.  The fries were decent.  I will not be returning.
author: Gopa K.

description:
Pan con chicharon was awful to much spicy cream and just one slice of sweet potato with bunch of rotten anions!! 
Plus the guy who took my order was making political claims and demanding to me and their customers to voto for Keiko otherwise he won't take care of our orders!!! 
I won't never ever buy from this food truck again
author: Maura G.

description: The lomo saltado sandwich was delish.  Good size, nice bread, meat was tasty.  Good showing at Sacto MoFo 5.
author: Jason G.

description: That Lomo Saltado though! Steak sandwiches are hard to do right. From my experience the steak is generally quite tough making the beef chewy and clumsy to eat in a sandwich. Sanguchon's Lomo Saltado NY strip steak was slow cooked to perfection. Soft, tender and bursting with this spicy/citrusy Peruvian flavour, the beef is complemented with tomato, onion, soy sauce, cilantro, and this cream de rocoto. The french artisan roll at Sanguchon was light, and very tasty. Overall this sandwich packed a punch with the beautiful Peruvian spices and flavours, while avoiding that heaviness from using a cream with such a heavy meat. Yum!
author: Kimberly C.

description:
This review is for their service and yuca fries. Which were both great!! Edgewood eats truck spot in Menlo park outside of willow market. 

Thanks guys!
author: Hungry L.

description:
I just loved it. It was our first visit to Off the Grid in Fort Mason, SF. We weren't too sure if we would get good options being vegetarians. 

We tried Vegetales al Curry and that was it. I couldn't resist to finish the whole wrap. The curry is the magic in it. I had never eaten Peruvian food before but now this one wrap makes me go try their sister restaurants given on their website.

Looking forward to take friends to their truck and try other dishes at their restaurants. I would recommend people to try them out.

http://www.sanguchonsf.com/index.asp
author: Avani S.

description:
I've tried both the Loma Saltado and the Pan Con Chicharron, and highly recommend both.  Try the Yucca fries too. That dipping sauce is cheezingly awesome, but the yucca fries are very filling. I've yet to finish that last bite.

The meaty chunks in each sandwich are tender and moist. The crispy outsides of the pork chunks, give a nice crunch in every bite, and is nicely complemented by the tangy pickled white onion slices.
author: Jed I.

description: Friend and I split the lomo saltado and the chicharron. Both were really good! Loved the plantain in the chicharron one.
author: Clara Y.

description:
Sanguchon sanguchon. What happened?? I remember the days when the meat used to pour outta my Lomo Saltado sandwich. Now, onions pour outta my sandwich. 

I had the Lomo Saltado from Sanguchon when they were at Off the Grid in Menlo Park last week. There was more bread than meat. I decided to try them out again today at The Willows Market Food Truck Night (instead of Koja Kitchen) and same story different day. At 9 bucks a pop, it's just not worth it anymore. I also got the yucca fries which were okay but a little tough ($4).

I used to love you guys but something changed.....most likely will not be back. Two stars for effort.
author: Bridget C.

description:
Everytime I know sanguchon is going to be in san jose, my husband and I go right away to eat lomo saltado and chicharron... its delicious!!!. You can tell when the beef if good and they serve good beef. I usually get the plantains (my favorite) with our maracuya juice! 
We were just there last night and we were very satisfied with our dinner... always our best choice when we are craving for peruvian cuisine. 
Customer service is great and the lady already knows what we want :) .  
We also just love going there because we can bring our dog and it is a different environment. . Sitting outside, good music,  people and BEST FOOD! what else can you ask for? 
I HIGHLY RECOMMEND IT!!!!
author: Sharon L.

description:
Tried the Lomo Saltado sandwich when Sanguchon was at the Fremont Street Eats.
The sandwich was tasty overall, the steak was tender and the onions, fries, tomatoes with it was a nice compliment. A bit overloaded on the onions but I took some out.
Prices were reasonable for the portion size. I would recommend to try this sandwich if you like Lomo Saltado! I still prefer the traditional dish with rice and the yummy juices but the sandwich is interesting to try.
author: Miss H K.

description: Lomo Saltado and Pan con Chicharron are my favorites.  I alternate every time I go get lunch.  They are on Wednesdays and Friday on California & Montgomery.  They are super friendly, the food is always fresh.  The combination package is a good deal.  You get the sandwich, sweet potatoes fries and a drink. Check it out!
author: Roberto A.

description: Soooooo happy you were in the Financial District today when I got out of my meeting.  Lomo Saltado bowl for the win and super friendly folks running the truck.  Don't ever change.
author: Drew P.

description: Look forward to a Barbacoa wrap with a fried egg every Tuesday!! They are super friendly and prompt making it the ultimate trifecta of food truck taste: good food, friendly service, and faster than anything else around!!
author: Adam T.

description:
Sanguchon was staffed by workers wearing t-shirts of  pervuian eateries affiliated with Sanguchon.

menu: lomo saltado, pollo ala brasa, barbacoa, pan con chicharron, criollo,  wraps, drinks, etc.

locale: crush, larkspur landing, (9/30)

sampling: criollo (8)
-lightly breaded chicken breasts  overflowing in tacu tacu salsa & aji amarillo sauce (resembles mayo)
-on round, custom made hamburger- like bun, a little chewy.
-chicken breast surprisingly tender. not dry.

foodnotes:
-pan con chicharron most popular, next on list to try, skipped cuz it sounded like fried pork rinds. :)
author: Victor G.

description:
I've had Sanguchon thrice now at random food truck rally's. Twice, I've walked away with "post-lunch food orgasm" and the other, extremely disappointed...

The Lomo Saltado is heaven on a bun. It's a steak sandwich that is juicy and loaded with flavor. One of the finest food truck sandwiches you'll ever eat...

The Pollo A La Brasa was the shits. It was plain and unimpressive. The pieces of chicken were not premium, had fat and grizzle, and a slimy texture. My wife and I didn't like it. And a few weeks later, I watched my friend disappointingly toss his in the trash after a few bites. I just shook my head and said, "Told you. Go with the Lomo..."

Stick to the Lomo (though I'm ready to try the Chicharone with Fried Yams next) and you'll leave happy.

4.5 stars.
author: Joel V.

description:
I tried Sanguchon when they stopped by Bishop Ranch in San Ramon. There was a line and I waited about 15 minutes. I ordered Their Pan Con Chicharron. It was a well made sandwich. The bread was crusty and delightful. There were generous amount of pork (belly?) in the sandwich. The pork was succulent and tender; a great match with sweet and strong red onions on it. I should have added their sweet potato fries but didn't. That would have been $14 total bill. Not really great in value. For an $8 sandwich, add a small side for fries or something, please! 

I'll probably try their Lomo Saltado and that's that. (Sides on the sandwich, please!)
author: Paul V.

description: Sanguchon consistently serves up tasty sandwiches.  My friend Bob adores this truck.  Now I can't see Sanguchon without thinking of my friend, Bob.
author: Lorianne L.

description: Wow! What a disappointment! I am Peruvian so I know what a good lomo saltado is, this was not good AT ALL! I ordered the lomo saltado bowl($10); the french friea were soggy, there's probably like 2 bites of rice, there was almost no tomatoes and onions and that is the hole point of a saltado, and the seasoning was waaaaaay off! I tried sanguchon 2 years ago and it was AWESOME, so i have no idea what happened to it. Would not recommend it at all! Again, that's my point of view as a Peruvian, but if uve never had Peruvian food, then you'll prob think it's ok.
author: Sylvana F.

description:
I came here twice because my brother kept insisting that I should give them another try because I didn't get the right sandwich. 

Well, I tried both sandwiches he suggested and I thought they were both dry and didn't have much flavor. I got the Pan con Chicharron and the Pollo a la Brasa. Both dry and tasteless. I wanted to like  hem because they sound good on the menu but the execution was terrible. I could have spent $8 elsewhere.
author: Denice D.

description: Making their debut in the south bay, I had to go check it out. Most of the Peruvian cuisine Im used to doesn't work well in truck delivery form. However the Sanguchon folks adapted things into sandwich form. Got the Chicharron sandwich with a side of empanaditas, Tasty. Now I was sad they were out of both chicha morada and maracuya. Hopefully they swing around again so I get those and see what Lomo Saltado in sandwich form is like
author: Kim N.

description:
I really love Peruvian food, so I was really excited to try the Sanguchon truck.

The Aji de Gallina wrap was pretty flavorless. Looking back at it, I really wish I had brought some hot sauce to toss on this wrap. Pretty disappointing.
