The BBQ Pork sandwich was good, but didnt taste Peruvian at all. It tasted like a BBQ Pork sandwich I'd have gotten back home growing up in Wisconsin.

Their chicha morada was just fine. I dont know how they make this drink so I dont know if you could even mess it up, but they certainly didnt.

Overall, its a 3. Wont have me running back, but would have it if there are no better choices.
author: Norman P.

description:
Peruvian sandwich truck with a pig logo...I couldn't wait to try it. I found Sanguchon at Off the Grid: Upper Haight. They had 4 types of Peruvian sandwiches served on French bread (lomo saltado, pollo ala brasa, barbacoa, pan con chicharron), 2 wraps, sides, drinks and some daily specials, including empanadas. I didn't know what some of the drinks were (and the menu didn't provide a description) but they sounded Peruvian. 

* Pan con chicarron ($8): Porktastic as some would say...massive chunks of lightly spiced luscious, tender pork...there was so much pork that I had to take some out to bite down on the sandwich. I liked how the slices of fried yam added some sweet creaminess. 

The bread is a warm, round white French roll (so the sandwich resembles a hamburger). The bottom of the roll was really hard and it fell apart a bit but it was still a good roll. The bread is made for Sanguchon. 

The sandwich was a bit too tall but I was happy with the filling to bread ratio, the crunch of the pickled onions and the creamy aioli. I think it would be even better with sauce on the side (something spicy and/or full of fresh herbs).
author: Lolia S.

description:
Even with a humongous line, service was friendly and fast. 

I got the lomo saltado and IT WAS DELICIOUS. The bread was a perfect crisp, the steak was tender, the fries added a unique touch, and all the ingredients were fresh. I can't even explain my love at first bite. Though $8 for a burger seems outrageous, this burger was definitely worth it.
author: Joanna C.

description: I tried the pan con chicharon sandwich and I must say that it was one of the best sandwiches I've had lately. There are so many different layers of flavor, that each bite is different. The sweet potato adds a nice dense sweet flavor while the pickle onions gives the sandwich a more tart flavor. I also enjoy the special sauce, it was a great creams compliment to the sandwich
author: Elba A.

description:
I had the Chicharron sandwich. It has sliced pork loin, fried yams, marinated onions, and some sauce I forgot the name of.

It was AMAZING. The pork loin was so tender I couldn't believe it was pork (I hate it when my pork becomes powdery tasting), whereas the other things in the sandwich really compliments the pork well. The bread is also great.

This makes for one of the best lunch sandwiches I've had. It's a must try!
author: Alice C.

description:
3.5 stars 

Tried Sanguchón at off the grid: fort mason on friday. I share a lomo saltado sandwich ($8) with the bf. Loved the roasted tomatoes & onions & potatoey fries that soaked up the soy sauce, but we both agreed the filet mignon (yes, filet!) they used that day was tender, but needed to be better spiced. Sandwich took on the shape of a burger, as the French roll was round--not much flavor & while it didn't overwhelm the filling, we left a lot of bread uneaten. 

I don't eat Peruvian food very often, but I'd be interested to try other items out of this truck: alfajores (of course!), roasted chicken, & fried plantains.

$10 credit card minimum.
author: Fancypants X.

description:
Liked:
Tequenos
Yucca Fries

Okay:
Chicha Morada (purple drank)

Disliked:
Pan con Chicharron
Plantanos Fritos
author: O M G.

description:
My first ever bite of Peruvian food came from this truck. I encountered them at the soft opening for OtG: Serramonte. And of course, I turned to my trusty Yelp app to see what I should order. I got the Lomo Saltado sandwich. It was really good! To my fellow Filipinos out there, it's very reminiscent of bistek. Wished the bread was toasted, but other than that, 'twas delicious. 

Definitely coming back.
author: Abigail D.

description: The Sanguchon truck pulled up near my office on a Thursday at lunch and I was excited to try them.  Once I visted their truck at Eat Real in Hayward and took a pass on them because they ran out of bread for their sandwiches.  I was in luck this time and ordered the lomo saltado and sweet potato fries combo ($10).  The sandwich was pretty good.  The beef wasn't dry like some people complained about and was good.  The fries were pretty limp though, making me wish I just ordered the sandwich by itself.  Overall, a pretty decent sandwich.  Not my first choice if multiple trucks are out there, but not a bad option either.
author: Jeff C.

description: finally got to try them a few days ago at the off the grid in Oakland. the combo (lomo Saltado burger, sweet potato fries, drink) was $12 and super filling! the inca cola was refreshing too! I'll definitely be back!
author: Stephanie K.

description:
Yum yum.  You gotta get some of this.  I tried the Pan con Chicharron (pork loin)  and Loma Saltado

1.  Pan con Chicharron (Pork Loin, yams, salso criolla, aji rocoto aioli) - This sandwich is good (not spectacular) but good.  For me the yams make the sandwich - creamy with a hint of sweet.  It has LOTS of chunks of pork meat; little fat, but enough to give good flavor.  

2.  Loma Saltado - Stir fried New Yoirk steak with tomato, onion, cilantro, - soy sauce and fries (yes, fries).  This sandwich rocks!  We are taking flavor city.  If you order both sandwiches, then definitely eat the pork first.

3.  Fried Plantains - great dessert.  Sweet, gooey...........$3.00 

Cost:  $8/bucks each.  Hmmmm.  if you are hungry then $16 is not a great value

Conclusion:  Know that I know the Beef is killer, then $11.00 is your average lunch these days so worth it.

TIP:  if you know the truck is in your area get a breakfast so you are not starving.  If you are starving then get ready to shell out extra bones for your lunch
author: Robert H.

description:
Service is consistently awful.  The truck is never at the spot on time, and opens it's doors around noon and not 11am as posted.  I took a few co-workers who were ordering for the first time, and the cashier gets very, very, frustrated with new folks who don't know it's a 10.00 credit card minimum,  change an item, add an item, and if you ask questions.  Cashier makes sure you know it by making the most awful annoying "i hate people" faces she can muster.  

Food is pretty good though. But the staff at this truck is terrible.  It reminds me of a bunch of knuckleheads who couldn't give a chit less about customers because the boss isn't around.
author: Logan B.

description: Tried this truck out when it was at the OMCA Off the Grid. I had their delicioso Lomo Saltado which is a sandwich with stir fried ny steak, tomato, onions, cilantro and fries. They come to Oakland almost every other week on Friday nights. I'm planning to try their other sandwiches when I go back. Wish I was eating one right now!
author: Candice J.

description: Heaven. Pure heaven.  Pan con Chiccaron (pork loin w/onions & yams) and Lomo Saltado (NY Strip Steak w/greens & fries).  You'll find no sandwich like these anywhere nearby.
author: David W.

description:
Overall: I have been wanting to try this truck for so long and now that I have I'm a bit disappointed


Cons
-Barbacoa sandwich is all bread
- chips in the sandwich are all soggy 
- the line for this truck is always long

Sidenote: I'm hoping that this was just bad day, we shall see
author: Michelle D.

description: This has to be the best food truck I have ever ordered food from. Today I ordered the Lomo Saltado Sandwich. It was amazing!! Seasoned steak stir fried with tomatoes sauteed onions and special sauce. I will be looking forward to the limited days they come to this corner. So far it seems to be Tuesday's and Thursday's 11:30 to some time in the after noon. I arrived early and was served at 11:10. I will update my review after a few more visits and try their other menu options
author: Ben M.

description:
I'm surprised that this place has only 19 reviews.  I think it's still under the radar a bit, but I can only imagine that this will be the next big food truck.  My boyfriend's half Peruvian, so we were psyched last week to go to OTG Fort Mason to try this truck.  Unfortunately, they were sold out of a lot of things, including the entrees we wanted - the Aji de Gallina wrap, and the Vegetable Curry wrap.  He got the Pan con Chicharron and I got... only an Inka Cola, because I don't eat meat :-(.  He loved his sandwich, saying that the flavors were authentic and reminded him of his childhood, which made me even more disappointed.

...But, there's a happy ending because Sanguchon was near my work at OTG UN Plaza today!  I got the long-awaited curry wrap.  And it was awesome!  I don't even like mushrooms that much, but theirs were delicious and tasted marinated.  The one downside was that they used the bottom of the asparagus and it was sometimes crunchy and hard to chew.  Otherwise the wrap was almost perfection; I just wish it was spicier.  I also got a package of the alfajores.  They were pretty meh and overpriced.  I would love to try the Yucca Fries and Tequenos!  Don't forget though that it's CASH ONLY.
author: Laura C.

description:
Two stars only because the gf really really wanted to come back here and try another one of their sandwiches. 

My first time? A few snafus. 

No yucca fries? fine, whatever, the platanos fritos were a decent alternative, but yucca fries are ALWAYS better. 

No huancaina sauce? Ya kiddin' me mijo? No son peruanos? How can you run out of that? 

Lomo saltado sandwich
Delicious (stir-fried steak, tomato, onion) until I got home and when I bit into it after a couple of bites a FREAKING DISGUSTING HAIR WAS IN MY SANDWICH. UGH! 

Girlfriend's chicken burrito thing was unremarkable, one-note, sort of bland, with a peanut sauce in it that just didn't go far enough to impart flavor to it. 


Other food trucks out there, definitely not coming back to this one, not even for the platanos (that I didn't want in the first place)
author: Ben G.

description: I whisper Sanguchón into the night sky and she does not respond... Every day when I don't taste "That Gooch" --as the locals call it-- my thirst grows until eventually it is impossible to quench. I recommend you get the sandwich.
author: Ben B.

description:
Tried this food truck on a whim at the America's Cup this past weekend while I was wandering around San Francisco on vacation. I've gotta say that I had a pleasant experience. I really had no idea what to order so I took a leap and ordered a Lomo Saltado based on a big picture on the menu, haha.

I've gotta say that it was one of the best sandwiches in a while I really enjoyed the bread that they used. It went perfect with the steak, french fries, and accompanying ingredients. Next time in town, I will definitely look up this truck to try more stuff on the menu.
author: Brian C.

description:
I had a craving to try something different. Sanguchón Peruvian Food Truck was in front of our building on the corner of Mission and Spear Street.

I ordered their chef special chicken sandwich; fried chicken with coleslaw and a layer of French fries.

How was this place rated a four stars place is beyond me!

It was an overcooked chicken with cold fries on a large bun that falls apart when you bite into it. The chicken was cold, dry and slightly burned; the fries were cold and soggy like it just came out of a freezer. The coleslaw was tasteless filled with onions.

Maybe this was a bad truck, I wasted $8.00!
author: Jeannie C.

description:
I tried this food truck when it came to Off the Grid at Serramonte. I'm surprised that the line wasn't longer for this truck because the sandwiches were pretty tasty and the price was more reasonable considering the amount of food you get (compared to other trucks).

We ordered the Pan con Chicharron and Lomo Saltado, both which came with sweet potato fries. Between the two sandwiches, I would say the Lomo Saltado wins hands down. The sauce they use was really tasty and is what made this sandwich the better of the two. The french bread used for the sandwiches was light and chewy. It was almost a little too soft to the point where it almost didn't hold up to the weight of the sandwich, but I think that's preferable to bread that's too hard and tough to chew.
author: Isabel D.

description: Walked up on this truck in Pleasanton. We got the yucca fries and pollito Al mani wrap. Both super good and the dipping sauce with the yucca fries had a good bite
author: Tabitha N.

description:
One of my favorite food trucks in all of San Francisco right now.  It's parked at 140 Spear Street Tuesday and Thursday at lunchtime.  

My standard order is the steak sandwich, with a spicy mayo, tomatos, and fries inside the sandwich, on a really good sweet bun.  They have the speed for the lunch rush down, and can get through their line efficiently.  

The best side on the menu is the fried plantains.  

This may be a bit of grading on a curve; I think street food in San Francisco is a bit overhyped and overpriced, and this feels like a good meal that makes me happy every time.  I was considering giving them four stars, but then realized due to number of checkins how often I go there, and how much I enjoy that sandwich.
author: Zachary R.

description: My first time trying Peruvian food, so I ordered the pollo a la brasa (braised chicken) sandwich. It took a long time to wait in line to order, and then even longer to get my food. The sandwich is a fair size, and stuffed with a lot of chunky ingredients, so things are falling out left and right. Each sandwich goes for about $8-$9...which I feel is overpriced for a sandwich that's just mediocre. It had decent flavor, but nothing really "Peruvian" about it. Basically just big hunks of meat, with loads of red onion, some tomato and some mayo, between two thick pieces of ciabatta bread. Sorry that my experience at Sanguchon was not very memorable.
author: Cammy C.

description:
I saw the food truck right next to La Boulange Bakery on California which I was planning to go to initially. But since I've had Peruvian food before, thought I should give the Lomo Saltado a try. Boy were my taste buds happy that I did!

The steak tenderness, the sauce, fries all worked so well together. The quality I would say was better than some Peruvian Restaurants in the city that charge $18 for the same food. 

Hands down the best sandwich I've had in a long time.
author: Ali A.

description:
Peruvian food has become one of my favorite cuisines over the last few years. The food in Peru is surprisingly some of the best food I've ever had out of all the foreign countries I've visited. The food is simple, yet complex. It can be sophisticated, yet still be homey and comforting at same time. I've eaten at high-end Peruvian restaurants and inexpensive family style ones all over Peru and in the Bay Area. The food has been consistent in quality and flavor.

Unlike the food at Sanguchón, which is a major disappointment. I'd be ashamed to even call it Peruvian food. It's simply bland and boring ethnically unidentifiable food. The Pan con Chicharron sandwich is merely a dry pork loin sandwich that needs more than a pinch of salt and tons more salsa criolla and aji rocoto aioli. The Aji de Gallina wrap is basically a majorly uneventful boring and bland chicken, rice and bean burrito with absolutely zero flavor.

As my fellow yelpers say, "I really wanted to like them, but meh, not so much."
author: Anastasia B.

description:
Now that food trucks are such a fad, I feel like it's easy to think it's amazing just because it came from a truck.  But really, there are oftentimes better places you can get that food truck entree and at better prices.  

There are still a handful of exceptions though, and this truck's pan con chicharron sandwich is one of them.  Generous amounts of pork, fried yams, pickled onions, and this aioli in a burger-sized sandwich.  Ordered a side of yucca fries, and I was happily stuffed!  Soooo delicious!  If you see this truck around, I recommend it.

TLDR: Pan con chicharron sandwich is a food truck item that is definitely worth it.
author: Carol L.

description:
Me and Mrs. Weez and our faithful pooch Bebe braved the gale force winds to go to the San Mateo food truck gathering this evening. By the time we got there, Bebe's head looked like it had exploded because the wind had blown her hair in so many directions! The farmers' market aspect of the affair had sensibly chosen to stay home since the winds were strong enough to push me around whenever I tried to stand still. There were four food trucks and a frozen custard truck which was sadly void of customers due to the weather, but I'll try it next time either way.

I decided to go with a new truck this evening and chose Sanguchon. The menu was a little limited, but the options sounded quite tasty and I also noticed that it was associated with La Costanera over in Half Moon Bay which I've enjoyed in the past. I got the BBQ pork sandwich which consisted of some very tasty fresh baked bread, some veggies, some home-made potato chips, and a nice helping of roasted pork and tangy / spicy barbecue sauce. The sandwich certainly looked amazing, but my first couple of bites were very fatty and gristle-y and I ended up throwing 90% of the meat away because it was all funny bits (chewy things you don't want to eat). This was a bummer because the flavor was so good! 

The truck was very clean and the staff were SUPER nice, but I'm seriously 
torn on how to review this. The food had good flavor, but gristle-y / fatty ingredients really ruined the overall experience for me. The flavor part would get 4 stars, but the meat was a 1 star at best. It wouldn't hurt them to trim the meat a little more. I would try it again, but go for something like the lomo saltado next time. If I do, I will upgrade this review (hopefully to 4 stars).
author: Jason W.

description:
Sanguchon!

We used to get the Pan de Chicharron pretty regularly but it would sometimes be a miss (dry). Especially on the weeks where it was up next to the Chairman's belly. But one week, on a whim, we ordered the Aji de Gallina wrap which kind of tasted like a chicken curry burrito. BEST. DECISION. EVER.

Plus, they have Inca Cola. Ah, brings back memories!
author: Salina Z.

description:
Found this truck at the Brisbane, I believe at the Walmart.com parking lot.

I tried the pan con chicarron. Pretty yummy, tender pork meat, good sandwich bread, but it needs more sauce. I feel the sandwich is a bit too big for my mouth most times, and the bread is a little bit too hard as well.

I think for a sandwich that's supposed to be eaten not at a dinner table, the format is kinda off. The meats fall off the sandwich and not a lot of sauce can be applied because it would've dripped off the sandwich too much.

Great idea, need a better execution.
author: Novalina N.

description:
Lomo saltado with Sweet Potato Fries?
Pan con Chicharron?

And apparently owned by the same guy who owns my favorite Peruvian restaurant near my house, La Costanera??!

AMEN! Hallelujah!

My date was kinda hot (fine, he was) but I didn't care if these were hard to eat with poise! Messy messy, did NOT give too much of a damn. I'll take the credit for choosing this truck among those parked by the Oakland Museum. Best choice at Oakland's Off the Grid.

I normally cannot finish an entire burger. But I made sure I finished most of this, not to impress ze guy, but because it was that good, it should not go to compost without my exhaustion.

The meat was tender and juicy and cooked juuuuust right, and the BREAD ITSELF WAS AWESOME!

The only negative thing was they ran out of their signature drink. Boo. Just a tiny, quiet boo. But the museum had a bar with wine and locally crafted beers so, it worked out.

I hope this truck lurks around FiDi. Does it?
author: Paulyne R.

description:
2 1/2 at best for this food truck so called marvel

Sampled there Lomo Saltado sandwich in theory this sounds delicious they way it was carried out not so great.

For the folks that don't know Lomo Saltado is grilled steak slices served usually on a plate with fresh cut red onions, fresh fried french fries and a vinegary sauce that is sucked up by white non sticky rice. The plate option is always a plus in my book but it being a food truck they modified the plate and served the meat, onions, sauce in a bun.  The bread is version of a soft sweet roll kinda looks like a ciabatta bread from jack in a box. The bread was ok, it just didn't mesh well with all that was going in between, the meat was tender red onions fresh cut, fries semi soggy but had some crunch depending on where you bit down. Best to have this served as a plate not a sandwich sorry folks i'm not a fan

would I sample this specific sandwich again? No. There was other options that offered porklion in the sandwich, I may venture a taste on that but as for now the Lomo Saltado again was a no go. For me the lomo saltado should always be offered on plate with some fresh white non sticky rice not in between 2 buns

food ** 1/2
price $ 8 bucks for the sandwiches
service **** very helpful and friendly
author: Clarence A.

description:
Just order the Lomo Saltado.

Monday night is Food Truck night at the Willow Market in Menlo Park and the Sanguchon Truck is often there. I've had the Lomo Saltado several times and it is always excellent. The sweet potato fries are very tasty too. I once ordered the pork sandwich and it was fatty chewy pork. I wouldn't recommend the pork.

I'm a big fan of Food Trucks and this is one of the better ones as long as you order the Lomo Saltado. Remember what I told you!
author: Craig H.

description: The food here was bomb! Made for a tasty lunch, but not the healthiest choice
author: Nick R.

description:
Good weight. Short wait.

I ordered the Lomo Saltado with a fried egg and when I say "Good weight", I mean that it had a good heft to it.  I had a moderate apetite (I'm a big eater) and "the Lomo" satisfied it.  With good flavor too!  The beef was tasty and tender, the sauce was a great compliment and the bun was fresh.

On top of all that, it was ready in no time and the window service was friendly.  I'll go back next time this truck shows up at the office.
author: John D.

description:
Their Lomo Saltado is awesome. Its stir fried steak with tomato, onion, cilantro soy sauce & fries (note the fries are in the burger) and its served on an airy brioche type of bread. 

Just make sure you have cash if you only plan on spending less than $10, they have a minimum for their credit card purchases. I ended up getting their Yucca Fries which I was excited about, the huancaina sauce was really good, but the fries were too thick and they weren't fully cooked on the inside. 

I'll go  back again soon, I'm curious to try the Pan con Chicharron.
author: Analisa S.

description: Peruvian food on a truck. Yes, it's no joke. Love the pork loin sandwich filled with fried yucca too. Loved it so much that I ordered a side order of fried yucca too. Pork was crunchy and moist. The bread was exceptional. A mouthful to eat.
author: Patrick Gabriel L.

description:
At my last visit to OTG, I wanted to try out something new, so I headed on over to Sanguchon.  I never really have Peruvian food, so I thought it was worth a shot.

They serve up a variety of sandwiches and wraps ($7-$8).  I tried the "aji de gallina," or chicken wrap.  The wrap (just like a burrito, made in a La Palma tortilla), was pretty decent sized, and contained chicken, some cheese, white beans, rice, and a yellow-ish sauce.  It somewhat reminded me of Thai yellow curry.  The whole thing was a bit carb-y tasting.  The white beans were pretty interesting, at first I thought that they were potatoes.  The flavor was a bit mild and the burrito wasn't as hot as I would have hoped it to be, but it was decent.

My friend had the barbacoa sandwich, which was humongous and sort of like your typical pulled-pork, BBQ sandwich.  She seemed to enjoy it quite a bit. 

Overall, I thought that the food was good, but I don't know if I'd order the same thing again.  I am one to try out different things, so I'm not sure when I"ll have it again.  If I do come back, I'll make sure to order the alfajores cookies that everyone seems to be raving about.
author: Samantha L.

description:
This was my first time having Peruvian food. That being said, and having had it off the menu of a food truck, I'm wholeheartedly sold. 

Not sure what I had, since my friend got it before I arrived to the city, but judging from the pictures, it was the Lomo Saltado sandwich. Fries, perfectly grilled strips of steak, a yummy mayo spread, marinated bell peppers and onions, and more on a soft crisp bun? Let me repeat myself by narrowing it down: FRIES. STEAK. SANDWICH.

Hands down one of the top food truck items I've ever had.
author: Valerie L.

description: I always wanted to try their sandwiches and always see long lines outside their trucks. So I did and tried their special prawn sandwich with french fries. I love the sauce as it was so delicious. However, I find that their prawns were super salty. I felt so thirsty after eating it. Otherwise, this place is not bad for lunch. I would come back to try other sandwiches. And as always, food trucks are expensive.
author: Elaine C.

description:
For $8, you get a large and delicious tasting pork burger/sandwich. It's a lot of food and the pork has a lot of flavor. I think it's absolutely delicious, but for those that don't like fat, beware of the fatty pieces of pork.

I actually haven't seen them in Potrero Hill for a while, so take note of that. I went a few days ago when they were parked on Spear and Mission in the FiDi.
author: Alfonzo J.

description: Out of nearly everything by 12:30pm. Save yourself the trouble and go elsewhere until they have enough to last a normal lunch day.
author: Nicholas D.

description:
I like the Chicharron better than the Lomo Saltado.  

Yucca fries were awesome.

Fatty Tip:  Do NOT try to eat two sandwiches, struuuuuggled to walk back to the office after doing so.
author: Steven F.

description:
There were a variety of food trucks at the Dew Tour. Saguchon's line was moving the fastest so I hopped on their line. I wanted my bang for my buck in terms of dollar to calorie. The Lomo Saltado sandwich seemed to accomplish this, "Stir fried New York steak with tomato, onion, cilantro soy sauce & fries."

This sandwich is great! I thought about going back to the truck and buying another sandwich for later. The Lomo Saltado is one of those great sandwiches that you can have with a beer, after partying, or if you're just really hungry. The bread is especially made for the sandwiches and it shows. It's so fresh, pillowy, and it has a delightful outer crust. The big chunks of beef combined with the carboliciousness of fries and veggies is delectable. I've never seen this food truck before but if I see them again I'll be pleased to jump on line again.

_____

Not the most elegant of sandwiches, but it satisfies mad hunger.
author: Michael H.

description:
The Pan con Chicharron was dry. Maybe it was later in the day, close to 2pm. All I got was dry pork on a hard bun. No veggies & no sauce. I did ask for no onions but it was lacking some acid maybe a slaw. Overall first time experience was disappointing. 

I decided to give it another chance.  This time I got the Lomo Saltado. Here's a tip for you- When you read the description it sounds like you are getting fries on the side. Actually, the fries are in the sandwich (like 4 pieces). So, don't get all excited and think you're getting a sandwich and fries for $8! 

The Lomo Saltado had tender steak, peppers, onions, tomato all tossed in a lime sauce. The sauce really helped to soften the otherwise hard bread. The bread is toasted and gets rock hard after 5 minutes. Best if eaten right on the spot! 

3 stars overall because they are overpriced for the serving sizes and because the wait for food is on the long side which is important when you only have an hour lunch break.
author: Giovanna F.

description: Go here for lunch.  Recommend getting:  lomo saltado.  best food truck of the bay.
author: Diane N.

description:
Sanguchon got so close to being so good,  
My foray into their menu was the Barbacoa which is Pulled BBQ Pork Spare Rib & Slaw served on a Brioche Bun, Plus I had a side of their Sweet Potato Fries ,  

It almost all worked except that the Bitter component of the Slaw was cut far to thick and dominated the topping of this Sandwich. But I loved the rest of the Sandwich which had its Meat well tossed in a light Mayo based sauce, Topped with a mix of Cilantro and Slaw. As for the Sweet Potato Fries they were thin cut, light and fragrant on the tongue, LOVED THEM ! 

I want to think the Slaw had Radicchio, but what ever the bitter green was I just hope the cooks of Sanguchon are more careful in the future so the Bitter vegetable does not dominate the slaw.
author: Joseph A.

description:
This truck is really good.  

The lomo saltado sandwich was awesome.  Kept the essence of the lomo saltado dish but transitioned it into a really great sandwich.  I'd go here again.  I wish it was down in the fidi more.
author: Mike I.

description: Lomo Saltado is a delicious creation! I first discovered this at Off The Grid in North Berkeley. It's a must try and worth the price!
author: Briget P.

description: This truck is pretty good. Really love the sandwiches. My only issue is the prices, but that's my issue with all food trucks. I can get double the food for the same price at any restaurant that serves the same food that any food truck does. But honestly this truck does make some delicious food so based on taste alone - this place rocks!!
author: Leo C.

description: I had one hell of a sandwich from these guys- the Pan con Chicharron.  Porky deliciousness, overflowing with meat, a great fresh tasting bun, fried sweet potatoes.  Really a delight of a meal.  Also tried their alfajores- fabulously constructed dulce de leche  filled cookies- great examples of one of my favorite cookies.  I'm looking forward to trying other offerings from Sanguchon- they have rapidly ascended up my food-truck rankings....
author: Andy S.

description:
They were at Logan High in Union City this week for one of the Food Truck Mafia events.  I normally go straight for the Korean tacos but this place intrigued me.  When we got to the truck, my hubby recognized them since he used to work at Potrero Hill, and remembered really liking their Pan Con Chicharron.

We had one each of their Pan Con Chicharron and the Lomo Saltado sandwich.  Maybe I've just been carb-deprived for a while, but their bread, which supposedly gets especially made for their truck, was really, really good.  Both sandwiches were great, but my favorite was the Pan Con Chicharron.  More like roast pork than chicharrones you're used to at Mexican places but I'll take my pig any way.  

I hope they come back to Union City!
author: Arlene M.

description:
I stopped by on a whim on during an errand and enjoyed their food at MVBL Feast. Their music set a good mood too and maid the wait go by more quickly.

The Aji de Gallina wrap was creamy and flavorful, providing a unique taste. The portion was large and the potatoes inside were very filling. Four stars.

The Lomo Saltado was a bit smaller and the flavor of its NY strip was closer to home, but  a little more pedestrian. Three stars.
author: Jason C.

description: It starts with a 20 minute wait to order and another 15 minutes for them to get me the right food I ordered. The lomo saltado was delicious as many of the reviews have stated. Tasty bread and well seasoned meat, think Peruvian Philly Cheese Steak. The Yucca frita in my opinion was not the best and the salsa amarillo could have been better (But I'm glad they limited the amount of garlic for the lunch crowd.) Since the yucca is prepared on the truck, I would have expected it to be hot and perfectly fried. What I received was a little soggy and lukewarm. The maracuya (A.K.A. Passion Fruit) was good and they didn't drown it in ice. Bottom Line: $8 for the lomo saltado + $4 Yucca Fries + $2 for the maracuya = $14 out the door meal. While not the cheapest meal in San Ramon it is a welcome visitor on a beautiful sunny day.
author: Chris S.

description: Sandwich is juicy and magical. If you start eating the sandwich, I'd recommend not putting it down because it'll get messy.
author: Eric C.

description:
Arrive early since the line gets really long and it takes them a L-O-N-G time to prepare each order.

I had the Lomo Saltado Sandwich ($8) and the Yucca Fries ($4).

The sandwich was quite good. It's stir fried steak, tomato, onion, cilantro, and fries on a bun. The bread was a little bit tough to bite off but soaked up the flavors of the stir fry well. The wrapper around the sandwich is probably one of the best of the food trucks I have tried since it stops anything from leaking out.

The Yucca Fries were quite a disappointment. You only get like 6 or 7 fries. They have a nice crunch to them but are very bland in flavor. The huancaina sauce that they come has the consistency of water and is also pretty flavorless. Definitely save your money and skip this dish.

I'll come back again to try their other sandwiches but I'm going to skip on the sides.

If the line is 15+ people deep....you should probably eat somewhere else.
author: Lester W.

description:
So I'm a noob when it comes to food trucks.  Scanning the parking lot at Stoneridge mall on Fridays, I feel overwhelmed and it's just a handful of 6-7 trucks.  I circled here twice w/ coworkers trying to take a stab in the dark, finally picking on Sanguchon at the last minute...you know like when you have 10 seconds left to fill out that scantron for your Psych 101 class.  And when in doubt just go w/ answer A.  In this case that would be the Chicharone with Fried Yams.

Maybe it was the unexpected delightful combination of warm toasty bread, crispy skinned pork (LOTS of it), and sweet yams on a drizzly Friday afternoon, but I really haven't had such a uniquely tasteful sandwich in a while.  And just the thought of it...I would seriously run these Peruvian bastards off the side of 580 if I saw their truck to get my hands on one of these sandwiches again.  Or on the other hand I could just hope they're out here in the parking lot next time I'm there...probably safer that way...and just follow em @Sanguchon_SF.
author: Glen G.

description:
OMG...i was craving beef and when i walked passed the food truck, i started to salivate, so obviously...i had to stop by....

I ordered the steak & fries sandwich - lomo saltado.  tender new york steak seasoned to perfection and topped with a heaping mound of fries.  oh, and ofr $8, it's a whole lot of beef. that sandwich was spilling over with juicy tender pieces of yummy yummy meat. oh, did i tell you they toasted the bun so it's so incredible crispy!

they are stopped in the financial district on california/montgomery street so for the portion/price combo, it's a steal.  

looking forward to trying the Chicharron sandwich on my next visit...
author: Ames K.

description: Had the Pan Co chicharon. It was mild tasting and didn't hit up any flavors that I wanted to taste. It was $8/sandwich.  Really nothing too special. I was disappointed.  We ate this at OTG in Serramonte.
author: Jboogie L.

description:
Sanguchon has been on my Bookmark list for quite some time. I finally had a chance to try them at Fort Mason during The Creators Project. 

My friend and I ordered two Lomo Saltado Sandwiches and Yucca fries.

The Lomo Saltado sandwiches were delicious! They gave generous portions of meat (which I appreciated), however, they weren't so generous when it came to the addition of fries.

I tried Yucca fries for the first time from this food truck and they were pretty good. They were a bit cold and they were in desperate need of salt. The sauce that came with the fries were also good, but, not great.
author: Juliette R.

description: Eh, it was ok.  I had the barbaoca, which was too sweet, too drippy, and really bland.  The "chips" added up to about 5 small potato chips made soggy, as they were in the sandwich, and the bottom of the sandwich was so wet and mooshy I couldn't pick it up, I just ate the pork with a fork.  If this is Peruvian food, I can do without.  My friend had the Lomo Saltado, and he commented on how bland and uninteresting it was.  I'm glad they came to the Pleasanton Green Fair, I like trying new food, and maybe Peruvian food is worth another taste, just not from this truck.
author: Rebecca H.

description: It's now my favorite food truck in San Francisco. My usual is the Lomo Saltado Combo, which comes with sweet potato fries and a drink. It is consistently delicious with a solid helping of steak and just the right portion of fries.
author: Greg M.

description: Yecch. I had the Lomo Saltado sandwich - the steak was dry and tough.  It was like eating a thick slab of cardboard. Plus they put french fries in my sandwich - how weird is that?
author: Allie C.

description: Wow. Really amazing sandwich. The Pan con Chicharron was awesome. The bread was fried and crispy without being greasy. The meat was crispy and flavorful and the toppings complemented the pork nicely. I wouldn't mind paying another 8 dollars for it even though it probably couldn't fill me up. Try the chicha morada too if you like sweet drinks.
author: Ruobin W.

description:
I got this for dinner at Off The Grid Berkeley (Southside) with some friends. 

I spent about $8 on the Lom Saltado and really enjoyed it! It was very huge and filling. I loved the steak and fries inside, along with the bread. The only word of advice I would give is to have a more flavorful sauce - maybe this is because I am a huge sauce girl though and just love sauce on everything.
author: Jenny M.

description:
Hayward's Off the Grid introduced me to this delicious delight. The Chiccaron Sandwich was cooked perfectly, especially the pork loin- moist and tender meat with a little bit of crispy skin to give it a bit of a crunch.
Also the fried plantains were pretty good. My 1 yr old really enjoyed them. Its a great option to have them cooking up quality meals this side of the Bay on Monday nights.
author: M P.

description:
I love the lomo saltado sandwich. The roll that it's served with is PERFECTION, the ideal mix of soft and chewy. The meat is flavorful without being overly salty, which I have unfortunately found is not the norm. I think it is my favorite thing I've ever eaten from a food truck, period.

I didn't have cash once and I needed to hit the credit card threshold so I ordered a chicha morada. It really did not do anything for me, so I will remember to always bring cash. Otherwise, I haven't tried anything else and honestly, I don't think I will. I won't knock 'em down a star though because I love the lomo saltado too much :)
author: Annie L.

description: I just had the most amazing sandwich!  This food truck rolled up to my work parking lot and I was definitely intrigued by Peruvian street food. They had several sandwich, wraps, and sides to choose from.  I had the lomo saltado with a fried egg.  I also had the yucca fries.  The sandwich was crazy big...It probably should have lasted me a couple days but it was soo good I couldn't stop eating it.  The steak was super tender and very well seasoned.  The sauce...whatever that creamy sauce was delicious!  The slice of lettuce helped cut all the fat that was in that sandwich.  The fried egg was delicious but not needed, this sandwich would be fine on its own!  The yucca fries were also tasty and the sauce they are served with was mouth watering.  Im not sure what it was but I would go back for that sauce ALONE!  The bread on the sandwich was really delicious as well, super crisp but not cut the top of your mouth crispy.  I CANNOT wait to go back and eat some more delicious Peruvian street food!!
author: Kate F.

description: The food is amazing and the service is equally great! I go out of my way to find this authentic food. The platanos are particularly my favorite. You will not be disappointed. Find this truck to enjoy!
author: Nila G.

description:
Deeeeeeelicious sandwiches!!!

On my first stop at this truck I went with the Pan con Chicharron, which is sliced pork loin with the clever and tasty addition of fried yams.  The bread/bun, which they boast is made especially for them, is awesome.

2nd time by I ordered the Lomo Saltado (NY steak, tomato, onion, cilantro) and again I had to refrain from wolfing it down in 30 seconds.  I also enjoyed the very tasty Chicha Morada, which is a beverage based with Peruvian purple corn with sugar, cinnamon, lime and a few other ingredients.  I say add vodka and you're REALLY onto something. ;-)

Sanguchon is a must try.
author: John K.

description: The slowest line we have ever stood in for a food truck. While the line wasn't that long, we waited an hour to place our order then another 30 minutes for our food. By the time we got to the front of the line, lomo saltado was the only sandwich left on their menu. Ours was stuffed with sweet potato fries instead, and it was pretty good but not worth the wait. Pass on the yucca fries. They were bland.
author: Sophia B.

description:
Hit up this truck at the Thurs Fremont stop off 880 in October but just getting around to review. Ordered:

* Lomo Saltado
* Yuca fries

Food (4.5 stars): 

Lomo was delicious. Meat was succulent, flavorful and ample. Bread was gourmet, Semifreddi's I think. Overall a delicious sammich. Fries were ok. Could have been well done (as requested), especially since no one else was waiting.

Service (1 star):

Lacking,...the young lady taking orders was not at all friendly or really cared to explain the various options. It was a "just order and go wait" attitude. Star deduction for Ms Personality. I had a fairly good idea what it was like but wanted to hear their slant/version. In fact, the self-proclaimed "gringo" who ordered 5 minutes after me asked me about the dishes. He also remarked that she was not "too friendly" so I gave him the 411 on what he just ordered. No bueno.

Value (1 star):

Poor
1 Lomo Saltado: $8.00
1 Yucca Fries:     $4.00
Total:                   $12.00

Overall:

I am going with 3 stars just because I loved the sammich and my guess is that I just was unlucky to order from the Ice Queen. No biggie. Value rating does not change though, still a poor value. I'd say charge $7 for sammich and $3 for the fries. $10 spot and your gone. It just feels better. Those are my 2 cents.
author: Rick G.

description:
I had the bbq wrap. it was amazing!!!

I'll seriously consider using them for catering too.

So good.
author: Tiff ..

description: Lomo Saltado - New York steak with tomato, soy sauce and fries - was surprisingly delicious; I was afraid it would be chewy steak meat, but it was very tender and juicy. I just wish the fries weren't so soggy, because although all together it tastes amazing, the texture would've been different. Overall a good eat. Will def order something else from their food truck!
author: Renata G.

description:
Authentic as you can get Peruvian fare out of the back of a food truck. Pricing as most urban food trucks seem to be getting these days, which I find hipster ironically humorous considering that the food truck were started as a means to bring cheap fast food to people in working areas that aren't that close to food. 

Anywhoo, had the Lomo Saltado sandy in Hayes Valley, couple months back. So freaking tasty. Almost, as good as a full OG dish of the stuff from Inka Mama's... Almost. 

Excited to try a new item, but the truck is hard to find and only in the city even remotely near me once a week. Bummer. 

I say if you see it try it out. Good Peruvian is hard to find in these parts. Sure you'll find uber authentic and NorCal bland, Fusion (aka americanized), whatever that often misses the mark of salty flavor so often found in non-SoCal offerings. But this does it.
author: Kelly S.

description:
I've been fortunate to have sampled eats from this truck a handful of times.  Each time has been at a different location (and perhaps a different truck/crew?). 

Still great: 
Lomo Saltado - steak sammich with onions, tomatoes, and fries.  Portion is great, the onions give it a nice bite, steak is perfectly seasoned, and the bread holds everything together.  One of our favorite sammiches to order. 

Take it or leave it: 
Sweet potato fries - cooked well, not greasy, good flavors

Chicha Morada - a fruity drink.  I don't know what it's *supposed* to taste like, but it was good and not overly sweet. 

Meh: 
Yucca fries - I don't know about you, but I usually like my fries *cooked*.  Call me a stickler for things like that.  The batch of yucca fries we had were thick cut and cooked through to about 1/8 of an inch.  Fairly inedible.
author: Shereen R.

description: Love this place!  My favorite is the pan con chiccarrones, but the special shrimp sandwich is tasty and filling also!  The folks working in the truck and friendly and lovely.  However, I do miss the fresh passionfruit punch . . . .
author: Sharon C.

description:
The food and service is awesome here!!! I will go back there for sure :)
I love the prawn burrito. The prawns were crunchy and the sauce makes it even better. U guys should try it!!
author: karla g.

description:
I think that this was the same food truck that I saw at Moveable Feast in San Jose.

There was a long line, so this was one of the more popular trucks.

I ordered the Pan con Chicarron, which was advertised as a pork loin sandwich with sweet potato and onion.

The bread tasted kind of like sourdough, and was soft, crusty, and fresh.

At first, I was skeptical of whether or not the meat was pork loin (as advertised), or pork shoulder. The texture of it was stringier than pork loin usually is.

The meat also could have benefitted from being braised or slow-cooked, which I think could have added more flavor to the sandwich and would have given it a softer texture as well. 

Luckily, though, the meat wasn't overcooked, which I was concerned about initially, so it wasn't bad, either. The meat portion was appropriate, and they give you a fair portion without having it be a gut bomber, though it wasn't piping hot. 

I asked for extra sauce, and it looked like they threw a tablespoon on it; I didn't see the value of the aioli sauce because there wasn't enough on it in order for me to decipher the taste.

There were less than five onion slivers, which tasted like they had been marinated in something sweet; there were prob less than five sweet potato slices inside of the sandwich.

They give you order numbers when you pay, yet they don't call 'em out when the orders are ready. So the boxes started to pile up at the window until you ask em about your order!

Last of all, $8 wasn't worth the food that I paid for! It was kind of on the high side as with a lot of these other food trucks. I could have gotten a McDonald's happy meal at half the price!

That's it, though. Kind of uneventful.
author: Jimmy L.

description:
I've never had Peruvian Food so I certainly don't know what I am talking about but I do know what's tasty and me likes what I had from this truck - yumms. We tried the pan con chicharron and the lomo saltado sandwiches.  Both delicious.  I like the bread they use for the sandwiches.  They hollow the rolls out a little so that the contents stay in place -- which I like because I just need the bread for the texture and as a holder for my goods. Don't need extra carb that performs no function but filler.  The pork loin in the pan con and the steak in the lomo were flavorfully marinated and tender.  

We had two of their drinks, which were a little sweet for us but we took them home and put spritzer water and in them and they were great with some fizz added to them.
author: Liz K.

description:
Tasty stuff.  Ordered the BBQ pork sandwich, on a delicious bun.  Stuffed inside were potato chips and slaw.  Not too much sauce.  Tender pork.  Will definitely revisit on a warmer day.  

Currently popping up at Mission and Spear on Tuesday.
author: Jeremy B.

description:
Sanguchon has been at a few Off the Grid events I've been to, in addition to what I believe is a rogue food truck outpost at Mint Plaza lately. They have a droolworthy menu and at least some of the people working there are actually Peruvian. Nice service and pretty quick getting food out. I recommend it.

I've taken off one star because I dream about platanos fritos, fried plantains. Literally, I dream of them. I had them once before from Sanguchon that were pretty good (not great), but last week my order was a big disappointment. Too dry to possibly enjoy. I might give them another chance, but it's not easy after a heartbreak as painful as that.

The rest of the menu items have been "on" all the time, as far as I can tell.
author: Ashley L.

description: One of my favorite places to eat.  I love Peruvian food and this food truck hits the spot!  I love the lomo saltado bowl and my desert - platanos.  If you are anywhere near the financial district I recommend this place as a go to option.  Friendly service and quality food.
author: Araceli F.

description:
Fresh ingredients, creative, delicious.   A well-balanced sandwich with good acids and rich savory flavors.  

Full disclosure, I did have a two fatty bites.. in my pork loin sandwich... but the good bites far exceeded the fatty.  If not for these two bites it would have been 10 out of 10.
author: Garrett G.

description:
On a whim, I tried Sanguchon for the first time at Moveable Feast on Alum Rock.  I don't know what I was expecting exactly, but the sauce in the sandwich was freaking delicious.  I had the Lomo Saltado (no onions), and because they ran out of fries, they filled my sandwich with chips instead, and that gave it a fantastic crunchy texture.

I'm so hungry now.  I need to find them.
author: Phuong T.

description:
The best, I mean THE BEST, alfajores I've ever had. I don't care about anything else as long as they keep on knocking out those alfajores. 

The rest of what I tried were delicious, but I forgot them all when I tried the alfajores.
author: Catherine S.

description:
ordered:

- Platano Frito $3 (Fried plantain with chicha sauce & salsa fusion) - delicious

- Pan con Chicharron $9 (Pork loin sliced, fried yams, marinated onions in lime juice & cream de rocoto) - a bit dry

will be definitely back for more plantains
author: Nadia Geddi T.

description: Boo for bad vegetarian food. So boring. Won't get food here again. Only gets a second star b/c they even have a veggie option at all.
author: Sadie G.

description:
that Pan Con Chicarron had my loins all moist.
pork was cut into nice chunks and kept all its juices.
the slaw +sweet potato complimented the pork nicely.
if i could add one thing, it'd be a bit more of the slaw/sweet potato. that's all.

gave the vegetarian wrap a try, to see if it was worthy of my vegetarian girlfriend. I thought it was okay.
author: Kenneth H.

description:
We ordered the Barbacoa sammy and some sweet potato fries.

Can you actually believe I am going to "bitch" about the amount of meat the sandwich had?  It had a TON of thick chunks of shredded pork.  The amount of sauce on the actually meat was minimal.  The amount of "orange sauce" that was on the bread was needed to moisten it up a bit.  The amount of slaw was lacking.... yeah I know say what you want but I like a bit of balance man.  I also was missing the crunch of the chips as promised.

Will I get that sandwich again, probably not.  I will however try another one next time around.

Sweet potato fries were just OK as I didn't notice anything special about them and probably wouldn't try those again either.
author: Tarra R.

description:
I just can't fathom that I paid $8 for the lomo saltado. 

My friend convinced me to eat at the food trucks rather than use commute to Boudin. I agreed because I usually enjoy food trucks. I'm still trying to figure out what I paid for. 

My beef was hard and cold, and there wasn't anything special. It's quite saddening actually. 

Also, $2 for a regular coke.
author: Adriana B.

description: Lomo saltado beef sandwich is really good. The beef  was tender and juicy. I really like the yucca fries. The fries come with mayo-like dipping sauce ( just Belgium fries :) .  The meal was filling and service was fast.
author: Hiroshi K.

description: I wanted to try the pan con chicharron so bad,but i never got the chance because they were to busy on their phones to take my order.So i just walked away. Very disappointed. That was so rude and unprofessional and very bad costumer service.
author: Nayeli A.

description:
A-Ok!

Sorry Clarence, I guess we disagree. I was impressed with the lomo saltado sandwich. Was it presented exactly how lomosaltado should be served? Nope. In terms of carbs lose the rice and put it in a sandwich.

The quality of the ingredients was good too. Fresh and tasty.

The lomosaltado could have been a bit juicer. I think knowing they're serving it in a sandwich they disn't make it as juicy as it normally is, probably so that we're not stuck with soggy bread, but it made the whole thing a little dry for me.

The pork loin sandwich was delicious!
author: Kym P.

description: The Chicharron was very good; the fried Plantains a little too sweet. Otherwise, quick service and not too pricey. -at Off The Grid
author: Collin P.

description: The food in this street truck is awesome,  I usually eat when I found them in SF, but I want to find out when are scheduled to be in Walnut Creek.  Recomended!!!!!!
author: Juan C.

description: Had the chicken wrap here, while the chicken was good and the sauce was great as well. Everything was overpowered by the abundant amount of rice. The whole thing felt like I am just eating rice wrapped in a tortilla with a sprinkle of tasty chicken. Not bad but not great.
author: Max N.

description: As far as food in the Financial District goes, this place is a gem! For $8 flat you can get a large sandwich with plenty of meat. I tried the pork belly sandwich and was pleasantly surprised at how good it was. The bread complemented the flavors of the meat and sauces perfectly. the sandwich was so large I could only eat half. I ate the other half for dinner later - is it weird that I thought the meat tasted better after being microwaved? (It made the meat softer and easier to chew, perhaps?). In any case, I would love to try this truck again, for the beef sandwich!
author: Mina K.

description: I am a loyal fan of the Truck Stop on Mission and 1st. Every day of the week, I would check their site or twitter to see who is coming for that day. When I saw Sanguchon Pervuvian food truck, I couldnt say no since I have never tried Peruvian food before. After eye their eye candy of a menu, I decided to go with Pan Con Chicharron. It looked amazing, but it was a different story when it came to eating it. The pork loin slice was overcooked. The meat was hard and dry, so it was a bit of a hassle to chew as all the meat would get stuck in between my teeth. My mouth was definitely getting worked. On the other hand, I liked the taste of my sandwich, the aji rocoto aioli was a bit lemony which gave it a kick and was refreshing. I wouldnt say no to trying Sanguchon again, I just wouldnt order the Pan Con Chicharron.
author: Becky Q.

description:
The pork sandwich was delicious.  I was thinking the pork would actually be "slivered" like it said in the sandwich description, but instead it was more like big hunks of meat.  Very tasty sandwich.  Don't let the idea of yams scare you away - the yam pieces weren't that big.  They were thinly sliced and added a hint of sweetness to the pork.  

My colleague got the sweet potato fries - super tasty.  Crispy on the outside soft on the inside, the way I love my fries.  The BBQ sauce it came with didn't really taste anything like BBQ - it had a gingery taste. 

The plantains on the other hand were gross.  Not sweet at all (only the pieces that had honey on them) and weren't fried like the El Salvadorian type plantains.  It was more like they were...baked.  And unripe.  Very mealy and starchy.  They were ok when hot, but got worse as they cooled down.  The concept with cinnamon and honey sounded delish, but sadly what was delivered was nothing worth your daily calorie intake. I would skip the plantains and go for the fries if you want a side!
author: Cheryl L.

description: I tried their Pork Sandwich and they gave generous servings! :) It was juicy and delicious!
author: Jasmine T.

description: Lomo Saltado!!  You know that you've got to try this sandwich when they feature two photos of it on the side of their food truck.  Not one, but TWO I repeat!   All their sandwiches sounded equally delicious but I had to go with the one that was stuffed with NY steak and fries topped with cilantro and onions.  Ran into this Peruvian food truck randomly on Brannan St and really glad I did.  The same group owns a couple restaurants in SF and one in Half Moon Bay if you want to try some of their classy Peruvian options w/o chasing down the food truck, be my guest.
author: Albie F.

description: Ignore the naysayers. This Peruvian-American and her Xicana  toddler loved  the food. I had the Criollo Sandwich, the little one ate maybe 1/8 of her ginormous aji de gallina wrap(which Daddy dutifully ate at home), shared a glass of fresh maracuya,  and we brought home two gigantic alfajores.  Glad the Mobile Gourmet hosts Sanguchon only once a month because I could see my new diet and exercise plan going to hell.  and if you don't know, now you know!
author: Julie C.

description:
I was at the Off The Grid at the UN plaza for lunch, when I saw that this truck had the longest line. That's gotta mean something good, right?
After a quick browse of their menu, I settled on the Lomo Saltado and an order of the Yucca Fries. 

As for the Lomo Saltado, which had beef, tomatoes, onions, and french fries. Their bread was nice and fresh, the beef was juicy and pretty tasty, and the french fries were definitely a good addition to give a little crunch to the sandwich.

That said, though, you'll want to eat the yucca fries first. The fries are thickly sliced, with a little bit of cheese melted on top, garnished with a bit of cilantro and served with a huancaina sauce (kinda cheesy, kinda spicy). When they're still hot and crispy, they're pretty good. Yucca fries are naturally bland, so they could use just a touch more salt, although the sauce adds a nice little kick. There aren't a lot that come in a box, so it's plenty for a single person, maybe not a lot if you're gonna share.
author: Y D L.

description: Yams, lime marinated pork, aioli on a delicious bun. Side of Yucca. Satisfying and filling, hit every flavor note. Great lunch option~!
author: Mark N.

description:
I'd never had Peruvian food before but Sanguchon enlightened me to the wonderful world of Peruvian sandwiches.
The barbacoa sandwich was absolutely terrific. Sanguchon heaps on piles of juicy tender barbacoa with coleslaw and, most interestingly, a layer potato chips. The chips added a nice crunch to the sandwich that I thought complemented the slaw very well. 

The house made bread is also very good, sort of spongy and is much richer than it looks. I thought the sandwich looked a little small but it truned out to be very filling. 

I want to try the Pan con Chicharron next time Moveable Feast comes around.
author: Kevin S.

description:
I approve!

Lomo Saltado sandwich was delicious!! 
The bread was good and held up the sandwich, decent amount of meat, and there's fries in the sandwich what??

It's a very good sandwich. It's no surprise that there's a line for this truck. I was skeptical at first because I never heard of the truck before but after looking through its menu I decided to give it a try and I am so glad that I did!! YUMMY!!!

I also ordered their Passion Fruit drink called Maracuya. It's ONLY $2!!! GOOD DEAL! Especially because drinks are so expensive these days o___O but it's freshly made they say, and it's 2 dollars! Yummy. And they don't put any ice in the cup so it might be a little room temperature-ish but at least they're not skimpy with filling up the cup with the passion fruit drink.

WIN!

I was gonna go back in line to grab another drink but the line had gotten VERY long. :) This truck will be very successful. Keep it up! :D
author: Khanh T.

description:
A buddy of mine recommended we assemble a fellowship of various characters from work in order to search out this rare Peruvian sandwich truck located in Ritch street in SF.   

After a brisk 20 minute walk we came upon the lot full of rivals we had to battle to claim our Peruvian Sangucheria goodies.

I promptly ordered the Lomo Saltado - a delicious concoction of grilled steak, onions, tomatoes, cilantro and soy sauce on a toasted roll.  This hit the spot!  The roll was crunchy and held the juicy goodness together quite well.  The steak was lean (but not too lean) and was well balanced with the sauce (savory) and onions.  The cilantro added the extra zip on top of the other favors.   One of the better sandwiches I've had!   Next time I will try the other varieties like chicken, pork etc because I heard those were equally excellent.  I paired mine with an Inka Cola - a surprising (once in a while) treat of fluorescent yellow bubblegum-like (but only a hint) flavored cola.  Worth trying if you've never had it.    We will definitely be back to this truck!!
author: Richard C.

description: I recently came across Sanguchon at Off The Grid-El Cerrito. I was super excited to try the Lomo Saltado. The sandwich was DELISH! Beef was perfectly cooked and full of flavor! Fries were nice and crispy and the bun was surprisingly perfect. The sandwich was humongous! Although I wanted to devour the entire thing - it was just too much to handle. Can't wait to try some of the other items on the menu:)
author: Krystal C.

description:
The streets of Peru are filled with street food especially late at night.  So this Peruvian sometimes just wants a quick bite.  Sanguchon certainly fills a void that's been missing in my life since I arrived in SF.  
I'm a fan of the lomo saltado sanguchon but whatever you order make sure to order the chicha morada to wash it down.
author: Roger H.

description: I love the lomo saltado sandwich. The steak is seasoned to perfection and it is super juicy. I really felt like I was biting into a nice hot dish of lomo saltado straight from Peru. The fries are super crispy and add an extra touch. The only thing I would recommend is thinly slicing the onions, but other than that it was an amazing experience and I cannot wait to try what the other items on their menu.
author: Cynthia A.

description: Move over Chairman Bao, I think I found a new favorite food truck! I might be biased because I went to Peru recently and these sandwiches are spot on (the pork sandwich was the same type I had in Lima). A bit nostalgic for me. Order the tequenos and the yucca fries too!
author: Melissa P.

description:
First, let me be clear that I may at some point revise my rating, as I am going on a very small sample (I had the yucca fries).

The fries were not good, at all. And yet they were four dollars, for a VERY small portion. And I don't mean "not good as in McDonald's fries", but rather, "even though there were not very many of them, 6 or 7 fries, I wasn't willing to eat them all, even knowing the price I paid for them."

Now, I DO intend to go back and try some of the other food (at which point I'll update the review if possible), because the food truck is very convenient for me to get to, and I really like to help support food carts/trucks. 

For the record, I wouldn't normally write a review after only trying a single item, but the fries were bad enough, and the price high enough (again, 4 dollars for a VERY small portion) that I felt compelled.
author: Kevin M.

description:
I don't think pork loin should be mostly fat.  Maybe the luck of the draw with my Chicharron sandwich but i was very disappointed.  I had the chicken wrap as well a few weeks ago and similarly disappointed.  With so much flavor packed into these items how can it go wrong?  it did.

The yucca fries and sauce were tasty but whatever meat they are using is suspect.  Seems to be real cheapie, based on my two visits (which is likely my final sampling).

If you are into your health, avoid.  otherwise, check it out yourself.
author: Jake S.

description:
Visited them outside of 3rd Door in Palo Alto and tried their Pan con Chicharron - very yummy!  The staff in the truck was super friendly and didn't try to oversell me when I asked if I should also get a side.

I would love to try other goodies on their menu!
author: Stephanie W.

description:
We tried Sanguchon (Peruvian Street Food) last night in front of Temescal Pool in Oakland.  The chicken sandwich was disappointing.  Lots of flavorless meat, a few tomatoes and onions, and some kind if mayo based sauce on a chewy bun.  On top of the mediocre food was the incredible wait to receive food, over 20 minutes.  Get a snack at another vendor while you wait.  

People seem to like the food (though from our sample, I don't know why) because not long after we placed our order, they were sold out of just about everything.  

If you have the opportunity, try Kiwicha, which also serves Peruvian food.  They offered only one item and that one item was awesome.
author: T W.

description:
Stopped by at Sactomofo4, They were out of regular food but i tried the fried plantains with the honey sauce and the peruvian cookies, both great.

Hope i can try their other food some time in the future.
author: Chris K.

description: Tried these guys for the first time at the 5M off the grid gathering.  The "Pan con Chicharron" was waaay better than I expected for a lunchtime sandwich.  Thick chunks of sliced tender pork loin, yams and other goodness made this trek worth it!
author: Linus W.

description:
Lomo saltado sandwich is great paired with an INCA COLA :) 
I am a regular, love it!
author: Ximena R.

description: Was trying to decide between the lomo saltado and the pan con chicharron and finally decided on the pork loin with fried yams.  The combination with the sauce was absolutely delicious.  For $8, it was a good sized sandwich but still leave you room to grab a taco from another truck.  Note:  the passion fruit juice is actually bottled and not fresh but still refreshing.
author: Joyce Z.

description:
Amazing, I had the Pan con chicharron (pork sandwich with fried yams, onions, aioli), the platano frito (fried plantains with honey and cinnamon), and a cup of the Chicha Morada (red corn punch, so good).

Everything was excellent. In San Francisco, the price is right and especially for the area. I went at 12:30 and there was no line but a few people's orders were being made. The special today sounded good but i didnt get it (some kind of cookie filled with dulce de leche).

The sandwich was $8 and definitely worth it for the high quality ingredients. Especially the bread: the bread was perfectly crunchy on the outside and just the right amount of soft, fresh baked feeling on the inside. The pork was tender and tasted like heaven-pork. It was new and exciting to have fried yams on the sandwich, too. I don't think I've ever knowingly had Peruvian cuisine.

You have to try this place. Cash only. Right by the park.
author: Maxfield A.

description:
I got the Pan con Chiccarone, Pork loin slivered, fried yams, marinated onions & aji rocoto aioli.  First of all, I wasn't expecting it to be so huge!  I'm used to having to order two things from most trucks to really make me full, and this would be enough alone.
It was also amazingly good.  I was thoroughly impressed.  I also got the wonton appetizer, and it was fantastic.  Fried with just the right amount of cheese inside and the avocado dip made it just perfect.  
Can't wait to go back.
author: Theo T.

description: Ordered the Pan Con Chicharron. The sandwich was good. The pork loins were very tender, moist and savory. The fried yams inside the sandwich gave it a nice contrast of flavors. Sweet and Savory! Even the bread had a nice crust while still soft on the inside. Though, $8 dollars? A little on the pricey side for just a sandwich.
author: Lorth K.

description: Get the Lomo Saltado and Yucca fries along with their homemade passion fruit juice and I promise you that you will have an orgasm in your mouth. One of the best food trucks I have eaten at. All that will cost you about $11
author: Kelvin B.

description:
OMG! There braised pork shoulder is SOO YUMMY! My company hired them for a private event and they served their pork side with sides of herbed raw onions and sweet potato mash. The pork was so tender you didn't even need a knife. 

I will definitely need to check them out again to get their yucca fries.
author: She R. A.

description:
Sanguchon has every right to be popular and run out of food by the end of the lunch hour.  Veggie wraps are the unicorn.  Just enough spicy to keep things interesting and a sweet, mild curry soaking into cooked vegetables.  The word 'crack' can be used to describe the tastiness of alfajores from Sanguchon.

For a food truck these guys turn out orders quickly.  I was lucky that they stopped by South San Francisco to serve the biotech companies in my work area.
author: Christine L.

description:
Tip:Poor service

I was at off the grid in Belmont last night. Walking through the parking structure and smelling all the deliciousness around me, it was hard for me to choose exactly where I wanted to go.
With a multitude of food trucks around me, I decided to walk past all except Sanguchon, where my eye caught the delicious looking sandwich plastered on the truck body. I decided to get the Barbacoa (an $8 barbecue pulled pork sandwich) and a bottle of water ($1) but the person in-charge wouldn't let me charge my credit card because they had a $10 minimum. I found this to be slightly pedantic especially since I was only a dollar short. They don't list the minimum anywhere that I could see and maybe some people may not want to spend $10 on a meal (since most people I know don't carry cash). I ended up purchasing two water bottles so I could pay for what I was now excited for.
The sandwich itself was very very good, probably the best I've had as far as pulled porks go so I would definitely recommend. Maybe a little light on the barbecue sauce though. 
 Was it $8? That's up to you to judge but I would get it again.
author: Minks M.

description:
Came across these folks as I meandered OTG Upper Haight on my daily walk home.  There was already a decent sized line so I decided it was good enough a sign to hop in line and decide on what to order as I waited. We settled on the following sandwiches and an order of yucca fries:

-Pan con chicharrone $7 (Pork loin slivered, fried yams, marinated onions & aji rocoto aioli) : our absolute favorite! The pork was soooooo tender and flavorful!  The sweetness of the fried yams complimented the pork and the aji rocoto aioli gave it the right amount of acid to pull it all together.  Would DEFINITELY go back for this one any day.  

-Lomo saltado $8 (Stir fried New York steak with tomato, onion, cilantro, soy sauce & fries) :  I love lomo saltado as a main dish at peruvian restaurants, so this sandwich was a must and they didnt disappoint.  The beef was cooked a perfect medium and seasoned well.   

-Yucca fries $4:  The box came out big, but the portion was a lil small.  We probably had about 8 fries, granted they were thicker than I'm used to. My friend said they were more like yucca wedges.  I feel like they wouldve been a lil better if they were fried just a little bit longer.  they were still good if you like yucca.  

Special mention to the french bread they use for the sandwiches.  Their menu says it is made specially for them.  It was the perfect balance between and crunch and chew, flavor didnt overpower the filling, and didnt fall apart w/ the sauces from the meat.  

If you need to filter through all the different  trucks at the OTG events, this is one truck you dont want to pass up.  Your belly will thank you for it!
author: Christina M.

description: Tried the Barbacoa sandwich and it was tasty.  The meat was moist and the slaw was good.  It had potato chips inside for an added crunch.  Teh bun was a good size.  Not sure this would be my first choice if multiple trucks are around, but it's definitely a good eat.
author: Josh L.

description:
Finally... a food truck that lives up to the hype!!  
Lomo saltado sandwich, Criollo sandwich, Aji de gallina wrap, Barbacoa sandwich, Yuca fries... all very yummy!  
Prices were good by food truck standards... I'm so over paying more than restaurant lunch prices at food trucks, for smaller portions.
author: Vandana N.

description: I ordered the Pan con Chicharron, the pork sandwich with fried yams (aka sweet potato fries), marinated onions, and aji rocoto aioli, on the cashier's suggestion. Got the food quickly, but the pork was pretty dry and was basically 50% straight fat. I liked the sauce though!
author: Caroline W.

description: I had high hopes for my Pan con Chicharron sando, but was really disappointed. The chunks of pork were super thick and hard to eat. Some pieces were so over cooked, they were like leather. The yucca fries suffered a similar fate. They too were so thick that the most were undercooked. Tough and unappetizing. The saving grace was the spicy mayo sauce for the fries.
author: I B G.

description: I rarely write yelp reviews, but I can't resist for these guys. The sandwiches are great, really hit the spot. The barbacoa sandwich is bomb and the service is fast and friendly.
author: Bryan P.

description: I tried the pan con chicharron and the chicken wrap. I found both surprisingly lacking in flavor but the meat was good in both. The sandwich had enormous pieces of pork in it, which tasted pretty decent, but parts were a little tough. All of the other components were overpowered. The wrap was unusual as it had a leafy component and was poorly composed - classic burrito-making mistakes making for uneven mouthfuls. I'm not really interested in returning.
author: Lisa K.

description:
Sanguchon was at the Friday food truck at Stoneridge Mall in Pleasanton. After working my way through the 10 other trucks I decided that Peruvian food would be the best place to start my Friday adventure. Something definitely different!

They seemed relatively popular yet kept the line moving fast. I ordered the Pan con Chicarron which was quiet tasty. Came in at $8 but it was loaded with pork and the onion flavour played off well with the sauce. I decided to try the maracuya (passion fruit juice) which was sweet and refreshing. Perhaps overkill at $3 but it's imported in. I was hoping to actually get a fresh juice, but then again it's a food truck.

It seemed that 2 others had issue with their larger orders (3+ sandwiches) while I was waiting to order/for more my food and though I was #49 I got my food at the same time as #45 but that can happen anywhere I suppose.

I would consider eating back here again during the next Friday food truck event.
author: Kevin M.

description:
Pork loin and steak (lomo) sandwiches were a little bland which was surprising because i was expecting a lot of flavor based on description and other reviews, bread was too thick. decent amount of meat

sides:
plaintains with honey and cinnamon were nice
sweet potato fries looked better than they tasted - and i love sweet potato fries
author: Annie c.

description:
YUM. and I only had the cookies! So delicious - powdered sugar shortbread sandwich cookies with dulce de leche in the middle. 

The line at this food truck was long and we had already eaten over at Chairman Bao, but next time I'll try the real food here. I overheard people saying it was legit.

I want another cookie!
author: Kristen S.

description: Pretty disappointing for an $8 sandwich. It was nice and big, but (1) it was a lot of bread, (2) the plentiful pork was very dry and lacked any flavor, and (3) the sauce was unexciting. I ate 1/2 and trashed the rest. How to make it better? The pork, the center piece, should be cooked less to retain the moistness. Offer some hot sauce or something.
author: A I.

description:
I'm already craving another Pan con Chicharron, and want to try everything else too.

Pork loin with red onion, thinly sliced yams and two sauces (a spicy sauce and some kind of aioli) on a huge, spongy bun. It's big, but it's worth every bite. Lots of flavors and contrasts all in one monster sandwich of much goodness.

This cart appears to have a very original, non cookie-cutter menu, as food trucks go, and is also affiliated with a couple supposedly good restaurants. It's a winner as far as I'm concerned.
author: S R.

description:
Just devoured their pulled pork sandwich and felt like I had to write a short review.  Hands down one of the messiest, tastiest pulled pork sandwich I've ever had!  It's freaking amazing!  I'm drenched in sauce down to my elbow.  The meat is well seasoned.  The bread is soft and spongy.  The slaw and potato chips added nice texture.

I can't wait for them to come to town again so I can try the other stuff on their menu.  Glad I made it out to Pleasanton Street Eats on this drizzly, cold day.
author: L H.

description:
Only reason they did not get 5 stars from me is because the 2nd time I came her I ordered the Steak Sandwich and ended up getting the Pork one instead. Lucky I will eat pork and it was still a solid sandwich, but the Steak Sandwich blows it away IMO.

The Yucatan Fries and the dipping sauce are also really tasty and a unique take on French Fries.

All in all a great food truck, just needs to pay a little more attention to the orders.
author: Raymond A.

description:
omgggggggggggggggggg all im gonna say is omg omg omg lol


lomo saltado sandwich, you made my day. service is off the hook, big ass  smile when i got there, chatty not overwelming, food 200% awesome.

please be around serramonte more often
author: Jorge O.

description:
I sampled the barbacoa pulled pork sandwich with coleslaw and potato chips for $8. It was sublime. Heaven on a bun. Mmm, oh baby baby. 

The meat was choice, tender and melt-in-your-mouth delicious. The creamy barbecue sauce had just enough spice and zest. 

Do yourself a favor and get this!!!
author: Teresa G.

description: My favorite sandwich! Lomo saltado with yucca fries, YUMMERS!
author: Ladyreyes R.

description: I ate here from the the Oakland Off The grid and everything I had was lackluster : a combination of bland and disgusting. I ordered the bbq sandwich as a wrap, the tequenos and the yucca fries. The yucca fries were bland and needed seasoning. The tequenos  were of the same quality of the generic frozen pizza bites from the 80's and the bbq pork tasted like there was a lot of generic safeway brand bbq sauce piled on. The sandwich wasn't edible for me because the sauce was disgusting. Sorry but next off the grid I'll be staying away from this truck
author: Mesha H.

description:
